Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the celestial court of the Jade Emperor
lived seven princesses. Each had their chosen place in court, but the youngest princess
had a special skill. She could pluck clouds from the sky
and spin them into the softest robes. Her work was so precise, not even the most expert eye
could find a seam. But her craft was the same day after day,
and she longed for new inspiration. Finally, the Queen Mother granted 
the weaver permission to visit Earth. The other princesses would accompany her to protect their sister 
from earthly dangers. Dressed in special robes that allowed them
to fly between Heaven and Earth, the sisters soared down from the sky. The weaver was in awe 
of the rolling hills and rivers, and the sisters decided to swim
in one of the glittering streams. As the weaver floated,
she dreamt about staying forever. Meanwhile, a lone cowherd
approached the riverbank. He came here often
to sweep his parent’s grave and speak with his only companion— a stoic bull who listened patiently 
to the cowherd’s sorrows. But upon seeing the weaver’s beauty,
the cowherd forgot his routine. While he longed to introduce himself,
his lonely lifestyle had made him timid. Thankfully, the bull saw his friend's
plight and offered some advice. He told the cowherd of the swimmer’s 
celestial origins and of her dream to stay on Earth; but also that she could only remain 
if she lost her ticket back to Heaven. As the cowherd approached,
the princesses flew away in fear— leaving their dreaming sister behind. While keeping her magic robes hidden, the cowherd offered his own garment 
as a substitute. And after gaining her trust, 
the pair began exploring the countryside. She was struck by his caring nature, and he learned to see 
the world’s wonder through her eyes. Before long, the two had
fallen deeply in love. The weaver and the cowherd
built a prosperous life. Their farm flourished, and the weaver 
taught her skills to local villagers. As time marched on, the pair was 
blessed with two healthy children, but their bull was growing old. Before he died, the bull implored
the family to keep his hide and use its magic at their time of need. While the husband grieved for his friend, the weaver’s mind turned
to her other family. Dusting off her magical robe,
she decided to pay a visit to the heavens. But when the weaver
swept into her old home, no one seemed surprised to see her. With a start, she realized
that barely any time had passed— for a year on Earth
was merely a day in Heaven. When her family learned of her new life,
they were enraged. How dare she waste her love on a human? The weaver tried to escape back to Earth, but the Queen Mother plucked 
a golden hairpin from her head and tore through the sky. A great gulf opened, forming a river
of stars between Heaven and Earth. Below, the cowherd trembled, but he also
remembered the bull’s final words. Hastily placing each child in a basket, he draped the bull’s pelt
over his back and hurtled upwards. Above the clouds, each lover attempted
to wade through the surging stars. But no matter how hard they struggled, the gulf between them
only grew wider. Day after day, the Queen Mother
watched without pity. Years passed, and the weaver 
and the cowherd had no one, except the passing magpies 
to cheer them on. Finally, their love moved
the Queen Mother’s heart. While she couldn’t forgive
her granddaughter entirely, the Queen Mother would allow the weaver
to meet her earthly family once a year. And so, in late summer, the magpies
form a bridge across the Milky Way, reuniting the weaver and the cowherd. At this time of year, millions of people
in East and Southeast Asian countries tell similar tales of these 
star-crossed lovers, celebrating their annual reunion.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The weaver was skilled at making ____ out of _____.
Options: A. Ropes; light, B. Baskets; bamboo, C. Shirts; silk, D. Robes; clouds
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is the youngest princess in the celestial court of the Jade Emperor? Options: A. The weaver, B. The Queen Mother, C. The cowherd's mother, D. The princess who is the sister of the weaver Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the weaver's special skill? Options: A. She can fly between Heaven and Earth, B. She can pluck clouds from the sky and spin them into the softest robes, C. She can communicate with animals, D. She can heal the sick Correct Option: B
Question 3: Why did the Queen Mother grant the weaver permission to visit Earth? Options: A. To punish her for her laziness, B. To allow her to explore the world and gain new inspiration, C. To test her loyalty to the celestial court, D. To reward her for her hard work Correct Option: B
Question 4: What happened to the weaver when she visited Earth? Options: A. She forgot her magical robes and was unable to return to Heaven, B. She fell in love with a mortal man and decided to stay on Earth, C. She was attacked by a group of demons, D. She was forced to return to Heaven immediately Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the bull's final advice to the cowherd? Options: A. To forget his love for the weaver and return to his old life, B. To keep the weaver's magical robes hidden and pretend to be a mortal, C. To tell the weaver of the bull's final words and remind her of her celestial origins, D. To ignore the weaver and focus on his own life Correct Option: C
Question 6: What happened to the weaver's family when they learned of her new life on Earth? Options: A. They were overjoyed and welcomed her back to the celestial court, B. They were enraged and tried to punish her for her disobedience, C. They were indifferent and didn't care about her decision, D. They were sad and tried to persuade her to return to Heaven Correct Option: B
Question 7: What did the Queen Mother use to separate the weaver from the cowherd? Options: A. A magical rope, B. A golden hairpin, C. A river of stars, D. A wall of fire Correct Option: C
Question 8: What did the cowherd use to carry his children across the river of stars? Options: A. A magical boat, B. The bull's pelt, C. A pair of wings, D. A magical rope Correct Option: B
Question 9: What happened to the weaver and the cowherd after they were separated by the river of stars? Options: A. They were reunited immediately and lived happily ever after, B. They were separated for a long time, but eventually reunited once a year, C. They forgot about each other and went their separate ways, D. They were punished for their disobedience and forced to return to their respective homes Correct Option: B
Question 10: Why do people in East and Southeast Asian countries tell similar tales of the weaver and the cowherd? Options: A. To celebrate their annual reunion, B. To commemorate the weaver's bravery, C. To honor the cowherd's loyalty, D. To remember the Queen Mother's kindness Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

Although the question wording is not identical, the intent and content of Question 2 align with the ground truth MCQ. Question 2 asks about the weaver's special skill, and the correct option (B) states that she can pluck clouds from the sky and spin them into the softest robes, which matches the correct option (D) in the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the celestial court of the Jade Emperor
lived seven princesses. Each had their chosen place in court, but the youngest princess
had a special skill. She could pluck clouds from the sky
and spin them into the softest robes. Her work was so precise, not even the most expert eye
could find a seam. But her craft was the same day after day,
and she longed for new inspiration. Finally, the Queen Mother granted 
the weaver permission to visit Earth. The other princesses would accompany her to protect their sister 
from earthly dangers. Dressed in special robes that allowed them
to fly between Heaven and Earth, the sisters soared down from the sky. The weaver was in awe 
of the rolling hills and rivers, and the sisters decided to swim
in one of the glittering streams. As the weaver floated,
she dreamt about staying forever. Meanwhile, a lone cowherd
approached the riverbank. He came here often
to sweep his parent’s grave and speak with his only companion— a stoic bull who listened patiently 
to the cowherd’s sorrows. But upon seeing the weaver’s beauty,
the cowherd forgot his routine. While he longed to introduce himself,
his lonely lifestyle had made him timid. Thankfully, the bull saw his friend's
plight and offered some advice. He told the cowherd of the swimmer’s 
celestial origins and of her dream to stay on Earth; but also that she could only remain 
if she lost her ticket back to Heaven. As the cowherd approached,
the princesses flew away in fear— leaving their dreaming sister behind. While keeping her magic robes hidden, the cowherd offered his own garment 
as a substitute. And after gaining her trust, 
the pair began exploring the countryside. She was struck by his caring nature, and he learned to see 
the world’s wonder through her eyes. Before long, the two had
fallen deeply in love. The weaver and the cowherd
built a prosperous life. Their farm flourished, and the weaver 
taught her skills to local villagers. As time marched on, the pair was 
blessed with two healthy children, but their bull was growing old. Before he died, the bull implored
the family to keep his hide and use its magic at their time of need. While the husband grieved for his friend, the weaver’s mind turned
to her other family. Dusting off her magical robe,
she decided to pay a visit to the heavens. But when the weaver
swept into her old home, no one seemed surprised to see her. With a start, she realized
that barely any time had passed— for a year on Earth
was merely a day in Heaven. When her family learned of her new life,
they were enraged. How dare she waste her love on a human? The weaver tried to escape back to Earth, but the Queen Mother plucked 
a golden hairpin from her head and tore through the sky. A great gulf opened, forming a river
of stars between Heaven and Earth. Below, the cowherd trembled, but he also
remembered the bull’s final words. Hastily placing each child in a basket, he draped the bull’s pelt
over his back and hurtled upwards. Above the clouds, each lover attempted
to wade through the surging stars. But no matter how hard they struggled, the gulf between them
only grew wider. Day after day, the Queen Mother
watched without pity. Years passed, and the weaver 
and the cowherd had no one, except the passing magpies 
to cheer them on. Finally, their love moved
the Queen Mother’s heart. While she couldn’t forgive
her granddaughter entirely, the Queen Mother would allow the weaver
to meet her earthly family once a year. And so, in late summer, the magpies
form a bridge across the Milky Way, reuniting the weaver and the cowherd. At this time of year, millions of people
in East and Southeast Asian countries tell similar tales of these 
star-crossed lovers, celebrating their annual reunion.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What did the cowherd come to the river to do?
Options: A. Pick grass for his bull, B. Sweep his parents’ graves, C. Swim, D. Read a book
Correct Option: B

Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that has a similar intent and content.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the cowherd's reason for coming to the river, which is to sweep his parents' graves. Among the generated MCQs, none directly ask about the cowherd's reason for coming to the river.

However, I can suggest that Question 3 is the closest in terms of intent and content, as it asks about the Queen Mother's reason for granting the weaver permission to visit Earth, which is related to the weaver's encounter with the cowherd at the river. Nevertheless, this is not a direct match.

If I had to choose a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ, I would suggest Question 3. However, I must emphasize that this is not a direct match, and a more accurate generated MCQ would be one that directly asks about the cowherd's reason for coming to the river.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3 (with the caveat that it's not a direct match)

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the celestial court of the Jade Emperor
lived seven princesses. Each had their chosen place in court, but the youngest princess
had a special skill. She could pluck clouds from the sky
and spin them into the softest robes. Her work was so precise, not even the most expert eye
could find a seam. But her craft was the same day after day,
and she longed for new inspiration. Finally, the Queen Mother granted 
the weaver permission to visit Earth. The other princesses would accompany her to protect their sister 
from earthly dangers. Dressed in special robes that allowed them
to fly between Heaven and Earth, the sisters soared down from the sky. The weaver was in awe 
of the rolling hills and rivers, and the sisters decided to swim
in one of the glittering streams. As the weaver floated,
she dreamt about staying forever. Meanwhile, a lone cowherd
approached the riverbank. He came here often
to sweep his parent’s grave and speak with his only companion— a stoic bull who listened patiently 
to the cowherd’s sorrows. But upon seeing the weaver’s beauty,
the cowherd forgot his routine. While he longed to introduce himself,
his lonely lifestyle had made him timid. Thankfully, the bull saw his friend's
plight and offered some advice. He told the cowherd of the swimmer’s 
celestial origins and of her dream to stay on Earth; but also that she could only remain 
if she lost her ticket back to Heaven. As the cowherd approached,
the princesses flew away in fear— leaving their dreaming sister behind. While keeping her magic robes hidden, the cowherd offered his own garment 
as a substitute. And after gaining her trust, 
the pair began exploring the countryside. She was struck by his caring nature, and he learned to see 
the world’s wonder through her eyes. Before long, the two had
fallen deeply in love. The weaver and the cowherd
built a prosperous life. Their farm flourished, and the weaver 
taught her skills to local villagers. As time marched on, the pair was 
blessed with two healthy children, but their bull was growing old. Before he died, the bull implored
the family to keep his hide and use its magic at their time of need. While the husband grieved for his friend, the weaver’s mind turned
to her other family. Dusting off her magical robe,
she decided to pay a visit to the heavens. But when the weaver
swept into her old home, no one seemed surprised to see her. With a start, she realized
that barely any time had passed— for a year on Earth
was merely a day in Heaven. When her family learned of her new life,
they were enraged. How dare she waste her love on a human? The weaver tried to escape back to Earth, but the Queen Mother plucked 
a golden hairpin from her head and tore through the sky. A great gulf opened, forming a river
of stars between Heaven and Earth. Below, the cowherd trembled, but he also
remembered the bull’s final words. Hastily placing each child in a basket, he draped the bull’s pelt
over his back and hurtled upwards. Above the clouds, each lover attempted
to wade through the surging stars. But no matter how hard they struggled, the gulf between them
only grew wider. Day after day, the Queen Mother
watched without pity. Years passed, and the weaver 
and the cowherd had no one, except the passing magpies 
to cheer them on. Finally, their love moved
the Queen Mother’s heart. While she couldn’t forgive
her granddaughter entirely, the Queen Mother would allow the weaver
to meet her earthly family once a year. And so, in late summer, the magpies
form a bridge across the Milky Way, reuniting the weaver and the cowherd. At this time of year, millions of people
in East and Southeast Asian countries tell similar tales of these 
star-crossed lovers, celebrating their annual reunion.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What did the cowherd use to fly up to heaven?
Options: A. The weaver’s clothing, B. A pair of baskets, C. A flock of birds, D. The bull’s pelt
Correct Option: D

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

The correct option in both questions is related to the bull's pelt, which is the key information being tested. The other options in Question 8 are also similar in style and content to the ground truth MCQ, making it the most similar generated MCQ. 

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 8.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
In the celestial court of the Jade Emperor
lived seven princesses. Each had their chosen place in court, but the youngest princess
had a special skill. She could pluck clouds from the sky
and spin them into the softest robes. Her work was so precise, not even the most expert eye
could find a seam. But her craft was the same day after day,
and she longed for new inspiration. Finally, the Queen Mother granted 
the weaver permission to visit Earth. The other princesses would accompany her to protect their sister 
from earthly dangers. Dressed in special robes that allowed them
to fly between Heaven and Earth, the sisters soared down from the sky. The weaver was in awe 
of the rolling hills and rivers, and the sisters decided to swim
in one of the glittering streams. As the weaver floated,
she dreamt about staying forever. Meanwhile, a lone cowherd
approached the riverbank. He came here often
to sweep his parent’s grave and speak with his only companion— a stoic bull who listened patiently 
to the cowherd’s sorrows. But upon seeing the weaver’s beauty,
the cowherd forgot his routine. While he longed to introduce himself,
his lonely lifestyle had made him timid. Thankfully, the bull saw his friend's
plight and offered some advice. He told the cowherd of the swimmer’s 
celestial origins and of her dream to stay on Earth; but also that she could only remain 
if she lost her ticket back to Heaven. As the cowherd approached,
the princesses flew away in fear— leaving their dreaming sister behind. While keeping her magic robes hidden, the cowherd offered his own garment 
as a substitute. And after gaining her trust, 
the pair began exploring the countryside. She was struck by his caring nature, and he learned to see 
the world’s wonder through her eyes. Before long, the two had
fallen deeply in love. The weaver and the cowherd
built a prosperous life. Their farm flourished, and the weaver 
taught her skills to local villagers. As time marched on, the pair was 
blessed with two healthy children, but their bull was growing old. Before he died, the bull implored
the family to keep his hide and use its magic at their time of need. While the husband grieved for his friend, the weaver’s mind turned
to her other family. Dusting off her magical robe,
she decided to pay a visit to the heavens. But when the weaver
swept into her old home, no one seemed surprised to see her. With a start, she realized
that barely any time had passed— for a year on Earth
was merely a day in Heaven. When her family learned of her new life,
they were enraged. How dare she waste her love on a human? The weaver tried to escape back to Earth, but the Queen Mother plucked 
a golden hairpin from her head and tore through the sky. A great gulf opened, forming a river
of stars between Heaven and Earth. Below, the cowherd trembled, but he also
remembered the bull’s final words. Hastily placing each child in a basket, he draped the bull’s pelt
over his back and hurtled upwards. Above the clouds, each lover attempted
to wade through the surging stars. But no matter how hard they struggled, the gulf between them
only grew wider. Day after day, the Queen Mother
watched without pity. Years passed, and the weaver 
and the cowherd had no one, except the passing magpies 
to cheer them on. Finally, their love moved
the Queen Mother’s heart. While she couldn’t forgive
her granddaughter entirely, the Queen Mother would allow the weaver
to meet her earthly family once a year. And so, in late summer, the magpies
form a bridge across the Milky Way, reuniting the weaver and the cowherd. At this time of year, millions of people
in East and Southeast Asian countries tell similar tales of these 
star-crossed lovers, celebrating their annual reunion.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: By the Queen Mother’s decree, the weaver and cowherd could meet _____.
Options: A. Once a day, B. Once a year, C. Once every 10 years, D. Never
Correct Option: B

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 9. 

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about the outcome of the weaver and the cowherd's situation after they were separated by the river of stars. The correct option, B, states that they were separated for a long time but eventually reunited once a year, which matches the information provided in the ground truth MCQ. 

Although the wording and options are not identical, Question 9 is the most similar generated MCQ in terms of content and intent.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the celestial court of the Jade Emperor
lived seven princesses. Each had their chosen place in court, but the youngest princess
had a special skill. She could pluck clouds from the sky
and spin them into the softest robes. Her work was so precise, not even the most expert eye
could find a seam. But her craft was the same day after day,
and she longed for new inspiration. Finally, the Queen Mother granted 
the weaver permission to visit Earth. The other princesses would accompany her to protect their sister 
from earthly dangers. Dressed in special robes that allowed them
to fly between Heaven and Earth, the sisters soared down from the sky. The weaver was in awe 
of the rolling hills and rivers, and the sisters decided to swim
in one of the glittering streams. As the weaver floated,
she dreamt about staying forever. Meanwhile, a lone cowherd
approached the riverbank. He came here often
to sweep his parent’s grave and speak with his only companion— a stoic bull who listened patiently 
to the cowherd’s sorrows. But upon seeing the weaver’s beauty,
the cowherd forgot his routine. While he longed to introduce himself,
his lonely lifestyle had made him timid. Thankfully, the bull saw his friend's
plight and offered some advice. He told the cowherd of the swimmer’s 
celestial origins and of her dream to stay on Earth; but also that she could only remain 
if she lost her ticket back to Heaven. As the cowherd approached,
the princesses flew away in fear— leaving their dreaming sister behind. While keeping her magic robes hidden, the cowherd offered his own garment 
as a substitute. And after gaining her trust, 
the pair began exploring the countryside. She was struck by his caring nature, and he learned to see 
the world’s wonder through her eyes. Before long, the two had
fallen deeply in love. The weaver and the cowherd
built a prosperous life. Their farm flourished, and the weaver 
taught her skills to local villagers. As time marched on, the pair was 
blessed with two healthy children, but their bull was growing old. Before he died, the bull implored
the family to keep his hide and use its magic at their time of need. While the husband grieved for his friend, the weaver’s mind turned
to her other family. Dusting off her magical robe,
she decided to pay a visit to the heavens. But when the weaver
swept into her old home, no one seemed surprised to see her. With a start, she realized
that barely any time had passed— for a year on Earth
was merely a day in Heaven. When her family learned of her new life,
they were enraged. How dare she waste her love on a human? The weaver tried to escape back to Earth, but the Queen Mother plucked 
a golden hairpin from her head and tore through the sky. A great gulf opened, forming a river
of stars between Heaven and Earth. Below, the cowherd trembled, but he also
remembered the bull’s final words. Hastily placing each child in a basket, he draped the bull’s pelt
over his back and hurtled upwards. Above the clouds, each lover attempted
to wade through the surging stars. But no matter how hard they struggled, the gulf between them
only grew wider. Day after day, the Queen Mother
watched without pity. Years passed, and the weaver 
and the cowherd had no one, except the passing magpies 
to cheer them on. Finally, their love moved
the Queen Mother’s heart. While she couldn’t forgive
her granddaughter entirely, the Queen Mother would allow the weaver
to meet her earthly family once a year. And so, in late summer, the magpies
form a bridge across the Milky Way, reuniting the weaver and the cowherd. At this time of year, millions of people
in East and Southeast Asian countries tell similar tales of these 
star-crossed lovers, celebrating their annual reunion.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which birds help the weaver and cowherd reunite?
Options: A. magpies   , B. swans, C. crows, D. doves
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is the youngest princess in the celestial court of the Jade Emperor? Options: A. The weaver, B. The Queen Mother, C. The cowherd's mother, D. The princess who is the sister of the weaver Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the weaver's special skill? Options: A. She can fly between Heaven and Earth, B. She can pluck clouds from the sky and spin them into the softest robes, C. She can communicate with animals, D. She can heal the sick Correct Option: B
Question 3: Why did the Queen Mother grant the weaver permission to visit Earth? Options: A. To punish her for her laziness, B. To allow her to explore the world and gain new inspiration, C. To test her loyalty to the celestial court, D. To reward her for her hard work Correct Option: B
Question 4: What happened to the weaver when she visited Earth? Options: A. She forgot her magical robes and was unable to return to Heaven, B. She fell in love with a mortal man and decided to stay on Earth, C. She was attacked by a group of demons, D. She was forced to return to Heaven immediately Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the bull's final advice to the cowherd? Options: A. To forget his love for the weaver and return to his old life, B. To keep the weaver's magical robes hidden and pretend to be a mortal, C. To tell the weaver of the bull's final words and remind her of her celestial origins, D. To ignore the weaver and focus on his own life Correct Option: C
Question 6: What happened to the weaver's family when they learned of her new life on Earth? Options: A. They were overjoyed and welcomed her back to the celestial court, B. They were enraged and tried to punish her for her disobedience, C. They were indifferent and didn't care about her decision, D. They were sad and tried to persuade her to return to Heaven Correct Option: B
Question 7: What did the Queen Mother use to separate the weaver from the cowherd? Options: A. A magical rope, B. A golden hairpin, C. A river of stars, D. A wall of fire Correct Option: C
Question 8: What did the cowherd use to carry his children across the river of stars? Options: A. A magical boat, B. The bull's pelt, C. A pair of wings, D. A magical rope Correct Option: B
Question 9: What happened to the weaver and the cowherd after they were separated by the river of stars? Options: A. They were reunited immediately and lived happily ever after, B. They were separated for a long time, but eventually reunited once a year, C. They forgot about each other and went their separate ways, D. They were punished for their disobedience and forced to return to their respective homes Correct Option: B
Question 10: Why do people in East and Southeast Asian countries tell similar tales of the weaver and the cowherd? Options: A. To celebrate their annual reunion, B. To commemorate the weaver's bravery, C. To honor the cowherd's loyalty, D. To remember the Queen Mother's kindness Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ. However, based on the context of the story, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the birds that help the weaver and cowherd reunite. A related generated MCQ is Question 9, which mentions the reunion of the weaver and the cowherd but does not specifically ask about the birds.

However, Question 9's correct option mentions that the weaver and the cowherd "were separated for a long time, but eventually reunited once a year." The transcript mentions that "in late summer, the magpies form a bridge across the Milky Way, reuniting the weaver and the cowherd." 

But since none of the generated MCQs directly ask about the birds, I will choose the generated MCQ that is closest in context to the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As Numberland’s best detective,
you thought you’d seen it all. But the desiccated corpses 
of prominent natural numbers— whole numbers greater than 0— have been showing up all over the city
for the past week. All of Digitopolis is on lockdown
from sundown to sunrise, and it’s still not enough to stop
what can only be described as a vampiric feeding frenzy. The police are helpless, 
and have turned to you. You put the missing persons case 
you’ve been investigating on hold and study the evidence. Here’s what you know: most victims have been completely
drained of their life’s essence. Some have a thin line of slime
separating digits— some of which were drained 
and others spared. Which leads you to mystery one: what’s the significance 
of the slime-lines, and why are certain digits untouched? Pause here to figure it out yourself. 
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 Let’s start by looking 
for a pattern in the victims. Why have some been fully drained,
and some slimed? Well, the slime-lined are in their prime— which is to say they’re prime numbers,
divisible only by 1 and themselves. Not a single one of the unslimed numbers,
on the other hand, is. Furthermore, the drained parts of the 
slimed primes are not, themselves, prime. When 71 got slimed, 7 was prime,
but 1 was not. If 461 had been split into 4 and 61,
the right side would have been prime, but instead it was split further
into non-prime digits. And when 2099 got slimed, 
the attacker went with 20 and 99, and was able to drain both. So you have a big problem. There are infinite potential victims: all non-prime numbers, and all prime numbers that can 
be slime-lined to reveal at least one non-prime number. In fact, you can only think of a few
numbers that aren't vulnerable. First of all, the one digit primes: 
2, 3, 5, and 7. Then primes like 23, which could only be
split into 2 and 3, both prime. These numbers are familiar, but why? Aha! Your missing person’s case. Someone is kidnapping the numbers
that can’t be drained: we’ll call them the immune. If you can identify the four immune 
who remain, perhaps you can get to them first
and figure out what’s going on. Who are the immune?
Pause here to figure it out yourself. Answer in 2 Answer in 1 There are 4 one-digit immune:
2, 3, 5, and 7. All have already been kidnapped. But every digit in all of the immune
must be one of those four numbers; otherwise there would be 
a non-prime split possible. That means there are only these 16
candidates among the two-digit numbers. The ones that are prime must be immune. We can eliminate anything 
that ends in 2 or 5, as they’ll always be divisible by 2 and 5. This diagonal is also out,
as they’re divisible by 11. If the digits of a number add
up to a multiple of 3, it’s divisible by 3. So that eliminates 57 and 27,
leaving these numbers. Which, upon double-checking, are, 
in fact, immune. We now have a strong starting point
for searching three-digit numbers: any 2 consecutive digits must be 
on the list of the two-digit immune. Those all end in 3 and 7, so the only possibilities
are these 8 options: the two-digit immune with additional
3s or 7s on their ends. 3 can’t follow 3,
nor 7 follow 7. And once again, adding the digits 
reveals that 237 and 537 are divisible by 3. 737 is 67 times 11, 
so that leaves just 373, which is, in fact, prime,
and therefore immune. Could a four-digit number be immune? No, any consecutive three digits
would have to be immune, and there’s no immune three digit
number that starts with a 7. You rush out, 
but reach each home too late, until the only immune left is 373. You’re in the nick of time to scare
off her would-be kidnapper; not the vampire itself but a minion. 373 explains that she and the other immune
are the subjects of an ancient prophecy that designated them as vampire slayers. They’d sometimes gather and try 
to figure out what a vampire is, but no one had the slightest idea. They found the idea of slaying
things quite distasteful. You both trail her would-be kidnapper
back to a foreboding castle. There you release the other 
kidnapped numbers and confront the vampire himself. He’s powerless before the slayers, 
but ever the pacifists, they round him up, return the lifeforce 
to his victims, and send him packing. Numberland is safe... for now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which one of these statements is true?
Options: A. 1 is a prime number., B. All prime numbers are odd., C. 2, 3, 5, and 7 are the only one-digit primes.
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary reason for the victims in the mystery being drained of their life's essence? Options: A. The victims are being targeted because they are prime numbers., B. The victims are being targeted because they are non-prime numbers., C. The victims are being targeted because they are in their prime., D. The victims are being targeted because they are not in their prime. Correct Option: A
Question 2: Which of the following numbers is an example of a prime number that was not drained? Options: A. 71, B. 7, C. 1, D. All of the above Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to the text, what is the significance of the slime-lines on the victims? Options: A. The slime-lines indicate that the victim is a prime number., B. The slime-lines indicate that the victim is a non-prime number., C. The slime-lines indicate that the victim is in their prime., D. The slime-lines indicate that the victim is not in their prime. Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the name of the detective who solves the mystery? Options: A. The narrator, B. The vampire, C. The minion, D. The slayer Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the ancient prophecy that designates the immune numbers as vampire slayers? Options: A. The prophecy states that the immune numbers will be the subjects of an ancient prophecy., B. The prophecy states that the immune numbers will be the vampire slayers., C. The prophecy states that the immune numbers will be the victims of the vampire., D. The prophecy states that the immune numbers will be the ones to stop the vampire. Correct Option: B
Question 6: Which of the following numbers is an example of a two-digit number that is immune? Options: A. 23, B. 57, C. 27, D. 37 Correct Option: A
Question 7: According to the text, what is the reason why the number 237 is not immune? Options: A. The number 237 is not immune because it is a prime number., B. The number 237 is not immune because it is a non-prime number., C. The number 237 is not immune because it is divisible by 3., D. The number 237 is not immune because it is not divisible by 3. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the role of the vampire in the story? Options: A. The vampire is the main character., B. The vampire is the villain., C. The vampire is powerless before the slayers., D. The vampire is a pacifist. Correct Option: C
Question 9: According to the text, what is the reason why the number 373 is immune? Options: A. The number 373 is immune because it is a prime number., B. The number 373 is immune because it is a non-prime number., C. The number 373 is immune because it is divisible by 3., D. The number 373 is immune because it is not divisible by 3. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the outcome of the story? Options: A. The vampire is defeated and the numbers are safe., B. The vampire is defeated but the numbers are not safe., C. The vampire is not defeated and the numbers are not safe., D. The vampire is sent packing and the numbers are safe. Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The most similar generated MCQ to the ground truth MCQ is Question 6: Which of the following numbers is an example of a two-digit number that is immune? Options: A. 23, B. 57, C. 27, D. 37 Correct Option: A.

However, this question does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ. A more similar question would be one that asks about the one-digit primes. 

A question that matches the ground truth MCQ more closely is not present among the generated MCQs. However, if I had to choose the most similar one, I would choose Question 2: Which of the following numbers is an example of a prime number that was not drained? Options: A. 71, B. 7, C. 1, D. All of the above Correct Option: B.

This question mentions the prime numbers and has an option that includes the one-digit prime '7', which is also mentioned in the ground truth MCQ.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 2.

things quite distasteful. You both trail her would-be kidnapper
back to a foreboding castle. There you release the other

but ever the pacifists, they round him up, return the lifeforce 
to his victims, and send him packing. Numberland is safe... for now.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As Numberland’s best detective,
you thought you’d seen it all. But the desiccated corpses 
of prominent natural numbers— whole numbers greater than 0— have been showing up all over the city
for the past week. All of Digitopolis is on lockdown
from sundown to sunrise, and it’s still not enough to stop
what can only be described as a vampiric feeding frenzy. The police are helpless, 
and have turned to you. You put the missing persons case 
you’ve been investigating on hold and study the evidence. Here’s what you know: most victims have been completely
drained of their life’s essence. Some have a thin line of slime
separating digits— some of which were drained 
and others spared. Which leads you to mystery one: what’s the significance 
of the slime-lines, and why are certain digits untouched? Pause here to figure it out yourself. 
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 Let’s start by looking 
for a pattern in the victims. Why have some been fully drained,
and some slimed? Well, the slime-lined are in their prime— which is to say they’re prime numbers,
divisible only by 1 and themselves. Not a single one of the unslimed numbers,
on the other hand, is. Furthermore, the drained parts of the 
slimed primes are not, themselves, prime. When 71 got slimed, 7 was prime,
but 1 was not. If 461 had been split into 4 and 61,
the right side would have been prime, but instead it was split further
into non-prime digits. And when 2099 got slimed, 
the attacker went with 20 and 99, and was able to drain both. So you have a big problem. There are infinite potential victims: all non-prime numbers, and all prime numbers that can 
be slime-lined to reveal at least one non-prime number. In fact, you can only think of a few
numbers that aren't vulnerable. First of all, the one digit primes: 
2, 3, 5, and 7. Then primes like 23, which could only be
split into 2 and 3, both prime. These numbers are familiar, but why? Aha! Your missing person’s case. Someone is kidnapping the numbers
that can’t be drained: we’ll call them the immune. If you can identify the four immune 
who remain, perhaps you can get to them first
and figure out what’s going on. Who are the immune?
Pause here to figure it out yourself. Answer in 2 Answer in 1 There are 4 one-digit immune:
2, 3, 5, and 7. All have already been kidnapped. But every digit in all of the immune
must be one of those four numbers; otherwise there would be 
a non-prime split possible. That means there are only these 16
candidates among the two-digit numbers. The ones that are prime must be immune. We can eliminate anything 
that ends in 2 or 5, as they’ll always be divisible by 2 and 5. This diagonal is also out,
as they’re divisible by 11. If the digits of a number add
up to a multiple of 3, it’s divisible by 3. So that eliminates 57 and 27,
leaving these numbers. Which, upon double-checking, are, 
in fact, immune. We now have a strong starting point
for searching three-digit numbers: any 2 consecutive digits must be 
on the list of the two-digit immune. Those all end in 3 and 7, so the only possibilities
are these 8 options: the two-digit immune with additional
3s or 7s on their ends. 3 can’t follow 3,
nor 7 follow 7. And once again, adding the digits 
reveals that 237 and 537 are divisible by 3. 737 is 67 times 11, 
so that leaves just 373, which is, in fact, prime,
and therefore immune. Could a four-digit number be immune? No, any consecutive three digits
would have to be immune, and there’s no immune three digit
number that starts with a 7. You rush out, 
but reach each home too late, until the only immune left is 373. You’re in the nick of time to scare
off her would-be kidnapper; not the vampire itself but a minion. 373 explains that she and the other immune
are the subjects of an ancient prophecy that designated them as vampire slayers. They’d sometimes gather and try 
to figure out what a vampire is, but no one had the slightest idea. They found the idea of slaying
things quite distasteful. You both trail her would-be kidnapper
back to a foreboding castle. There you release the other 
kidnapped numbers and confront the vampire himself. He’s powerless before the slayers, 
but ever the pacifists, they round him up, return the lifeforce 
to his victims, and send him packing. Numberland is safe... for now.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The vampire’s goal with the slime lines is to:
Options: A. Scare his victims., B. Isolate prime sequences in order to drain them., C. Isolate non-prime sequences in order to drain them.
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the Egyptian Book of the Dead,
there’s a banishment spell that declares, “Be far from me, 
O vile cockroach.” More than 3,000 years later, 
we’re still trying to oust these insects. But from poison traps 
to hastily brandished slippers, cockroaches seem to weather 
just about everything we throw at them. So what makes cockroaches so hard to kill? There are nearly 5,000 cockroach species. 99% of them live in a range of habitats
where they play important ecological roles by recycling dead or decaying 
organic matter and nourishing other animals. But a couple dozen species adapted to live
in close association with humans. German and American cockroaches
are among the most common. And they owe their resilience
to a combination of physical and chemical adaptations. When it comes to old-fashioned 
removal methods, they're troublingly tenacious. An American cockroach’s sensory hairs 
or structures pick up subtle air currents and rapidly send signals 
to its central nervous system. The roach can then turn and sprint
away within a few milliseconds. And it’s among the fastest invertebrates
ever recorded, reaching speeds of up to 50
body lengths per second. This would be the human equivalent of
running more than 300 kilometers per hour. And finding a hiding place is no problem. With its flattened, flexible body, an American cockroach can squeeze into 
spaces less than a quarter of its height. Even if we do land a hit, 
it can withstand compressive forces of up to 900 times its own weight 
by distributing the impact along its body. And the cockroach’s toughness
doesn’t end there. Cockroaches can eat a variety 
of organic matter, including hair, dead skin, 
adhesives, and paper. This is made possible by an expansive set 
of digestive enzymes. Cockroaches are able to thrive 
even in nutrient-poor environments. Roaches often eat decaying foods
that are low in nitrogen— an essential component
of DNA and proteins. But they survive by storing 
nitrogen-containing wastes in their bodies and having a resident group
of bacteria recycle the nitrogen into useful molecules for them. Meanwhile, German cockroaches
will eat their own poop, vomit, and dead or dying colony members 
without hesitation. An American cockroach will
frolic in sewers, consuming excrement and toting microbes
like Staphylococcus aureus and E.coli. But they’ll rarely suffer
any consequences. This is because they’re equipped 
with genes that provide immunity against numerous pathogens. These genes are often duplicated 
many times over. So when infected, the cockroach’s 
immune system efficiently unleashes many antimicrobial molecules. Cockroaches also have a slew of defenses
against pesticides. When a non-resistant roach walks 
on a surface that’s been sprayed with a pyrethroid insecticide, 
for example, the results will likely be fatal. Once absorbed, the chemical binds
to sodium channel proteins, which help propagate nerve impulses. The pyrethroid keeps 
the sodium channels open, so the nerves fire repeatedly. And soon, the cockroach dies. But if a resistant roach is exposed 
to pyrethroids, it’ll be just fine. Genetic mutations have given
them sodium channels that the pyrethroids can’t bind to. The cockroach also produces more
detoxification enzymes, which render the pesticide harmless, and the cockroach simply excretes 
it as a waste. Because German cockroaches
reproduce especially quickly, populations may evolve resistance 
to a new pesticide within months. So far, they're already resistant
to 43 different chemicals. But contrary to popular belief, cockroaches would probably not survive 
a nuclear apocalypse. Compared with other insects, cockroaches are only mildly
tolerant to radiation. They would die near the sites
of nuclear explosions and would still be severely
compromised miles away. Moreover, disasters that threaten humanity also jeopardize the habitats and buffets 
we provide roaches. Perhaps the only way to beat them 
is through our mutual destruction. Or maybe cockroaches would find 
even more surprising ways to thrive long after we’re gone.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which factors do cockroaches owe their resilience to?
Options: A. Physical and chemical adaptations, B. Environmental factors, C. Psychiatric factors, D. None of the above
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the spell that declares, "Be far from me, O vile cockroach" in the Egyptian Book of the Dead? Options: A. Banishment Spell, B. Cockroach Curse, C. Insect Incantation, D. Pest Patrol Correct Option: A
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is one of the reasons why cockroaches are hard to kill? Options: A. They have a strong sense of smell, B. They are very fast, C. They have a combination of physical and chemical adaptations, D. They are very large Correct Option: C
Question 3: What would be the human equivalent of an American cockroach's speed of up to 50 body lengths per second? Options: A. Running 50 kilometers per hour, B. Running 300 kilometers per hour, C. Running 50 meters per second, D. Running 50 kilometers per minute Correct Option: B
Question 4: How do cockroaches survive in environments with low nitrogen levels? Options: A. By storing nitrogen-containing wastes in their bodies, B. By eating nitrogen-rich foods, C. By using special enzymes to break down nitrogen, D. By relying on other animals for nitrogen Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is one of the ways in which cockroaches have adapted to live in close association with humans? Options: A. By developing a strong sense of smell, B. By becoming resistant to pesticides, C. By adapting to a variety of environments, D. By evolving to live in sewers Correct Option: D
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is one of the reasons why cockroaches are able to thrive in environments with low nutrient levels? Options: A. They have a specialized digestive system, B. They are able to recycle nutrients from their waste, C. They have a strong sense of smell, D. They are able to store nutrients in their bodies Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is one of the ways in which cockroaches have developed immunity against pathogens? Options: A. By producing antimicrobial molecules, B. By developing a strong sense of smell, C. By becoming resistant to pesticides, D. By using special enzymes to break down pathogens Correct Option: A
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is one of the reasons why cockroaches are able to withstand compressive forces of up to 900 times their own weight? Options: A. They have a strong sense of smell, B. They are able to distribute the impact along their body, C. They have a specialized digestive system, D. They are able to store nutrients in their bodies Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is one of the reasons why cockroaches are able to survive in environments with high levels of radiation? Options: A. They have a strong sense of smell, B. They are able to produce special enzymes to break down radiation, C. They are able to store nutrients in their bodies, D. They are only mildly tolerant to radiation Correct Option: D
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is one of the reasons why cockroaches may be able to survive a nuclear apocalypse? Options: A. They are able to withstand high levels of radiation, B. They are able to survive in environments with low nutrient levels, C. They are able to recycle nutrients from their waste, D. They are able to survive in environments with high levels of radiation Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about the factors that contribute to cockroaches' resilience, and both have options that mention physical and chemical adaptations as the correct answer.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2

of bacteria recycle the nitrogen into useful molecules for them. Meanwhile, German cockroaches
will eat their own poop, vomit, and dead or dying colony members 
without hesitation. An American cockroach will
frolic in sewers, consuming excrement and toting microbes
like Staphylococcus aureus and E.coli. But they’ll rarely suffer
any consequences. This is because they’re equipped 
with genes that provide immunity against numerous pathogens. These genes are often duplicated 
many times over. So when infected, the cockroach’s 
immune system efficiently unleashes many antimicrobial molecules. Cockroaches also have a slew of defenses
against pesticides. When a non-resistant roach walks 
on a surface that’s been sprayed with a pyrethroid insecticide, 
for example, the results will likely be fatal. Once absorbed, the chemical binds
to sodium channel proteins, which help propagate nerve impulses. The pyrethroid keeps 
the sodium channels open, so the nerves fire repeatedly. And soon, the cockroach dies. But if a resistant roach is exposed 
to pyrethroids, it’ll be just fine. Genetic mutations have given
them sodium channels that the pyrethroids can’t bind to. The cockroach also produces more
detoxification enzymes, which render the pesticide harmless, and the cockroach simply excretes 
it as a waste. Because German cockroaches
reproduce especially quickly, populations may evolve resistance 
to a new pesticide within months. So far, they're already resistant
to 43 different chemicals. But contrary to popular belief, cockroaches would probably not survive 
a nuclear apocalypse. Compared with other insects, cockroaches are only mildly
tolerant to radiation. They would die near the sites
of nuclear explosions and would still be severely
compromised miles away. Moreover, disasters that threaten humanity also jeopardize the habitats and buffets 
we provide roaches. Perhaps the only way to beat them 
is through our mutual destruction. Or maybe cockroaches would find 
even more surprising ways to thrive long after we’re gone.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The ability of pest cockroaches such as the American cockroach to escape stomping attempts by humans can be attributed to which of the following characteristics.
Options: A. Walking or running speed, B. Flattened and flexible body, C. Both “a” and “b”, D. None of the above
Correct Option: C

Question 2: According to the transcript, what is one of the reasons why cockroaches are hard to kill? Options: A. They have a strong sense of smell, B. They are very fast, C. They have a combination of physical and chemical adaptations, D. They are very large Correct Option: C
Question 3: What would be the human equivalent of an American cockroach's speed of up to 50 body lengths per second? Options: A. Running 50 kilometers per hour, B. Running 300 kilometers per hour, C. Running 50 meters per second, D. Running 50 kilometers per minute Correct Option: B
Question 4: How do cockroaches survive in environments with low nitrogen levels? Options: A. By storing nitrogen-containing wastes in their bodies, B. By eating nitrogen-rich foods, C. By using special enzymes to break down nitrogen, D. By relying on other animals for nitrogen Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is one of the ways in which cockroaches have adapted to live in close association with humans? Options: A. By developing a strong sense of smell, B. By becoming resistant to pesticides, C. By adapting to a variety of environments, D. By evolving to live in sewers Correct Option: D

They have a specialized digestive system, B. They are able to recycle nutrients from their waste, C. They have a strong sense of smell, D. They are able to store nutrients in their bodies Correct Option: B

They are able to survive in environments with high levels of radiation Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the Egyptian Book of the Dead,
there’s a banishment spell that declares, “Be far from me, 
O vile cockroach.” More than 3,000 years later, 
we’re still trying to oust these insects. But from poison traps 
to hastily brandished slippers, cockroaches seem to weather 
just about everything we throw at them. So what makes cockroaches so hard to kill? There are nearly 5,000 cockroach species. 99% of them live in a range of habitats
where they play important ecological roles by recycling dead or decaying 
organic matter and nourishing other animals. But a couple dozen species adapted to live
in close association with humans. German and American cockroaches
are among the most common. And they owe their resilience
to a combination of physical and chemical adaptations. When it comes to old-fashioned 
removal methods, they're troublingly tenacious. An American cockroach’s sensory hairs 
or structures pick up subtle air currents and rapidly send signals 
to its central nervous system. The roach can then turn and sprint
away within a few milliseconds. And it’s among the fastest invertebrates
ever recorded, reaching speeds of up to 50
body lengths per second. This would be the human equivalent of
running more than 300 kilometers per hour. And finding a hiding place is no problem. With its flattened, flexible body, an American cockroach can squeeze into 
spaces less than a quarter of its height. Even if we do land a hit, 
it can withstand compressive forces of up to 900 times its own weight 
by distributing the impact along its body. And the cockroach’s toughness
doesn’t end there. Cockroaches can eat a variety 
of organic matter, including hair, dead skin, 
adhesives, and paper. This is made possible by an expansive set 
of digestive enzymes. Cockroaches are able to thrive 
even in nutrient-poor environments. Roaches often eat decaying foods
that are low in nitrogen— an essential component
of DNA and proteins. But they survive by storing 
nitrogen-containing wastes in their bodies and having a resident group
of bacteria recycle the nitrogen into useful molecules for them. Meanwhile, German cockroaches
will eat their own poop, vomit, and dead or dying colony members 
without hesitation. An American cockroach will
frolic in sewers, consuming excrement and toting microbes
like Staphylococcus aureus and E.coli. But they’ll rarely suffer
any consequences. This is because they’re equipped 
with genes that provide immunity against numerous pathogens. These genes are often duplicated 
many times over. So when infected, the cockroach’s 
immune system efficiently unleashes many antimicrobial molecules. Cockroaches also have a slew of defenses
against pesticides. When a non-resistant roach walks 
on a surface that’s been sprayed with a pyrethroid insecticide, 
for example, the results will likely be fatal. Once absorbed, the chemical binds
to sodium channel proteins, which help propagate nerve impulses. The pyrethroid keeps 
the sodium channels open, so the nerves fire repeatedly. And soon, the cockroach dies. But if a resistant roach is exposed 
to pyrethroids, it’ll be just fine. Genetic mutations have given
them sodium channels that the pyrethroids can’t bind to. The cockroach also produces more
detoxification enzymes, which render the pesticide harmless, and the cockroach simply excretes 
it as a waste. Because German cockroaches
reproduce especially quickly, populations may evolve resistance 
to a new pesticide within months. So far, they're already resistant
to 43 different chemicals. But contrary to popular belief, cockroaches would probably not survive 
a nuclear apocalypse. Compared with other insects, cockroaches are only mildly
tolerant to radiation. They would die near the sites
of nuclear explosions and would still be severely
compromised miles away. Moreover, disasters that threaten humanity also jeopardize the habitats and buffets 
we provide roaches. Perhaps the only way to beat them 
is through our mutual destruction. Or maybe cockroaches would find 
even more surprising ways to thrive long after we’re gone.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which word or term best describes the dietary preference of pest cockroaches such as the German and American cockroach?
Options: A. Vegetarian, B. Carnivorous, C. Omnivorous, D. Eggetarian
Correct Option: C

by distributing the impact along its body. And the cockroach’s toughness
doesn’t end there. Cockroaches can eat a variety 
of organic matter, including hair, dead skin, 
adhesives, and paper. This is made possible by an expansive set 
of digestive enzymes. Cockroaches are able to thrive 
even in nutrient-poor environments. Roaches often eat decaying foods
that are low in nitrogen— an essential component
of DNA and proteins. But they survive by storing 
nitrogen-containing wastes in their bodies and having a resident group
of bacteria recycle the nitrogen into useful molecules for them. Meanwhile, German cockroaches
will eat their own poop, vomit, and dead or dying colony members 
without hesitation. An American cockroach will
frolic in sewers, consuming excrement and toting microbes
like Staphylococcus aureus and E.coli. But they’ll rarely suffer
any consequences. This is because they’re equipped 
with genes that provide immunity against numerous pathogens. These genes are often duplicated 
many times over. So when infected, the cockroach’s 
immune system efficiently unleashes many antimicrobial molecules. Cockroaches also have a slew of defenses
against pesticides. When a non-resistant roach walks 
on a surface that’s been sprayed with a pyrethroid insecticide, 
for example, the results will likely be fatal. Once absorbed, the chemical binds

Question: Which mechanisms allow cockroaches (particularly German cockroaches) to tolerate and survive pesticide exposure?
Options: A. Detoxification enzymes, B. Mutations in the target site proteins, C. None of the above
Correct Option: B

**Transcript**:
In the Egyptian Book of the Dead,
there’s a banishment spell that declares, “Be far from me, 
O vile cockroach.” More than 3,000 years later, 
we’re still trying to oust these insects. But from poison traps 
to hastily brandished slippers, cockroaches seem to weather 
just about everything we throw at them. So what makes cockroaches so hard to kill? There are nearly 5,000 cockroach species. 99% of them live in a range of habitats
where they play important ecological roles by recycling dead or decaying 
organic matter and nourishing other animals. But a couple dozen species adapted to live
in close association with humans. German and American cockroaches
are among the most common. And they owe their resilience
to a combination of physical and chemical adaptations. When it comes to old-fashioned 
removal methods, they're troublingly tenacious. An American cockroach’s sensory hairs 
or structures pick up subtle air currents and rapidly send signals 
to its central nervous system. The roach can then turn and sprint
away within a few milliseconds. And it’s among the fastest invertebrates
ever recorded, reaching speeds of up to 50
body lengths per second. This would be the human equivalent of
running more than 300 kilometers per hour. And finding a hiding place is no problem. With its flattened, flexible body, an American cockroach can squeeze into 
spaces less than a quarter of its height. Even if we do land a hit, 
it can withstand compressive forces of up to 900 times its own weight 
by distributing the impact along its body. And the cockroach’s toughness
doesn’t end there. Cockroaches can eat a variety 
of organic matter, including hair, dead skin, 
adhesives, and paper. This is made possible by an expansive set 
of digestive enzymes. Cockroaches are able to thrive 
even in nutrient-poor environments. Roaches often eat decaying foods
that are low in nitrogen— an essential component
of DNA and proteins. But they survive by storing 
nitrogen-containing wastes in their bodies and having a resident group
of bacteria recycle the nitrogen into useful molecules for them. Meanwhile, German cockroaches
will eat their own poop, vomit, and dead or dying colony members 
without hesitation. An American cockroach will
frolic in sewers, consuming excrement and toting microbes
like Staphylococcus aureus and E.coli. But they’ll rarely suffer
any consequences. This is because they’re equipped 
with genes that provide immunity against numerous pathogens. These genes are often duplicated 
many times over. So when infected, the cockroach’s 
immune system efficiently unleashes many antimicrobial molecules. Cockroaches also have a slew of defenses
against pesticides. When a non-resistant roach walks 
on a surface that’s been sprayed with a pyrethroid insecticide, 
for example, the results will likely be fatal. Once absorbed, the chemical binds
to sodium channel proteins, which help propagate nerve impulses. The pyrethroid keeps 
the sodium channels open, so the nerves fire repeatedly. And soon, the cockroach dies. But if a resistant roach is exposed 
to pyrethroids, it’ll be just fine. Genetic mutations have given
them sodium channels that the pyrethroids can’t bind to. The cockroach also produces more
detoxification enzymes, which render the pesticide harmless, and the cockroach simply excretes 
it as a waste. Because German cockroaches
reproduce especially quickly, populations may evolve resistance 
to a new pesticide within months. So far, they're already resistant
to 43 different chemicals. But contrary to popular belief, cockroaches would probably not survive 
a nuclear apocalypse. Compared with other insects, cockroaches are only mildly
tolerant to radiation. They would die near the sites
of nuclear explosions and would still be severely
compromised miles away. Moreover, disasters that threaten humanity also jeopardize the habitats and buffets 
we provide roaches. Perhaps the only way to beat them 
is through our mutual destruction. Or maybe cockroaches would find 
even more surprising ways to thrive long after we’re gone.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In comparison to some other insects such as certain fruit flies and flour beetles, how can the tolerance of cockroaches to radiation be described?
Options: A. Highly tolerant, B. Susceptible, C. Mildly tolerant, D. Immune or completely tolerant
Correct Option: C

The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 9. 

This question is the most similar because it directly addresses the topic of cockroaches' tolerance to radiation, which is the main focus of the ground truth MCQ. The correct option, "They are only mildly tolerant to radiation," aligns with the correct answer in the ground truth MCQ, which states that cockroaches are "mildly tolerant" to radiation compared to other insects.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 9

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Every year before the ancient Greeks
sowed their seeds of grain, they celebrated Demeter, 
the goddess of agriculture. On Earth, each morsel of food 
was sweet sustenance, while in the land of the dead,
it ensured a permanent stay. Demeter tended to Earth’s fields 
with her beloved daughter, Persephone, who inherited her mother’s passions
and grew into a bright young woman. But all the while, a shadowy figure
watched from below. One day, Persephone was frolicking
in a meadow with a freshwater nymph, Cyane. As they admired a blooming
narcissus flower, they noticed it tremble in the ground. Suddenly, the earth split, 
and a terrifying figure arose. It was Hades, god of the dead
and the underworld. He wrenched Persephone from Cyane,
dragged her into his inky chariot, and blasted back through the earth. Cyane wept so hard she dissolved,
becoming one with the river. By the time Demeter arrived 
at the scene of the abduction, the crater in the meadow had closed—
and Cyane and Persephone had vanished. Demeter sped to Mount Olympus for help. Many of the gods had witnessed the scene. And they knew about the deal 
that paved the way for it: Zeus, Persephone’s father, 
had granted Hades her hand in marriage without her consent— or Demeter’s. But when faced with Demeter’s pleas, 
the other gods stayed silent, So, she searched alone. In her grief and desperation, 
she neglected her usual tasks. Crops withered, and a great famine 
plagued the Earth. As mortals began to perish, 
the gods grew wary. Who would worship them and 
offer tributes if the humans disappeared? So, Zeus ordered Demeter to stop 
her crusade and returned to her duties. But she refused. Deep below, across the frigid river Styx,
and through the halls of the underworld, Persephone was waging her own protest. Hades expected her to serve
as his wife and queen. But Persephone rebuffed the god’s advances
and refused food. As she longed for her mother’s company, her friends’ laughter,
and the sun’s warmth, Persephone grew colder and lonelier. And she was starving. She hungered for satisfying grains,
crisp vegetables and fresh fruit. Wandering the ghostly gardens, she contemplated the pomegranates 
that hung heavily on their branches... Meanwhile, Demeter continued her hunt. She appealed to the all-seeing sun god,
Helios, whose rays had long warmed her crops. Indeed, when Helios drew his golden
chariot across the sky that fateful day, he saw what happened— 
and he knew of the deal. Out of respect and sympathy for Demeter, Helios told her of Hades’ demands,
Zeus’ betrayal and Persephone’s abduction. Furious and heartbroken, Demeter sped
to Mount Olympus and confronted Zeus, demanding their daughter’s return. But Zeus declined: in her ravenous hunger, Persephone had eaten a few seeds from the 
pomegranate that grew in the underworld. Though a meager amount, it was enough
to ensnare her in Hades forever. Demeter wouldn't accept this fate. She swore that if she wasn’t
reunited with Persephone, the fields would never be fertile again, and the distinction between the Earth 
and the underworld would soon dissolve. So, they made a pact. For two thirds of every year, Persephone 
would return to the land of the living, But for the remainder, she would stay 
in the world of the dead. When Persephone ascended to Earth,
she and her mother rejoiced. Together, they showered the fields 
with rain and nurtured them with sun. For mortals, Persephone’s arrival came
to herald the start of spring. But her descent always came too soon. Each time she returned to Hades, 
Demeter mourned, and the earth grew cold, 
dark, and unyielding, ushering in the winter months. Knowing Demeter couldn’t be roused 
from her grief, the humans stored their crops, 
stoked their fires, and awaited Persephone’s safe return. And so it was that her transit marked
the gradual turning of the seasons and the bittersweet compromise
between life and death.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Demeter was the Greek goddess of:
Options: A. Love, B. Agriculture, C. Animals, D. Parenthood
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was the goddess of agriculture in ancient Greek mythology? Options: A. Athena, B. Artemis, C. Demeter, D. Aphrodite Correct Option: C
Question 2: What was the name of the freshwater nymph who was with Persephone when she was abducted by Hades? Options: A. Cyane, B. Echo, C. Calliope, D. Chloris Correct Option: A
Question 3: What was the name of the god who granted Hades permission to marry Persephone without her consent? Options: A. Zeus, B. Poseidon, C. Hades, D. Apollo Correct Option: A
Question 4: What was the result of Demeter's grief and desperation after Persephone's abduction? Options: A. The earth became fertile and crops grew abundantly, B. A great famine plagued the earth and crops withered, C. The seasons changed and the weather became unpredictable, D. The gods grew stronger and more powerful Correct Option: B
Question 5: What did Persephone refuse to do in the underworld? Options: A. Serve as Hades' queen, B. Eat food, C. Meet with her friends, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 6: What was the name of the god who told Demeter about Hades' demands and Zeus' betrayal? Options: A. Helios, B. Apollo, C. Artemis, D. Ares Correct Option: A
Question 7: What was the result of Persephone eating a few seeds from the pomegranate in the underworld? Options: A. She was able to return to the land of the living immediately, B. She was able to stay in the underworld forever, C. She was bound to the underworld for part of every year, D. She was able to meet with her mother again Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the compromise made between Demeter and Zeus regarding Persephone's time in the underworld? Options: A. Persephone would stay in the underworld forever, B. Persephone would return to the land of the living immediately, C. Persephone would spend two thirds of every year in the underworld and one third in the land of the living, D. Persephone would spend half of every year in the underworld and half in the land of the living Correct Option: C
Question 9: What was the result of Persephone's return to the land of the living? Options: A. The earth became cold and dark, ushering in winter, B. The earth became fertile and crops grew abundantly, heralding the start of spring, C. The seasons changed and the weather became unpredictable, D. The gods grew stronger and more powerful Correct Option: B
Question 10: What marked the gradual turning of the seasons in ancient Greek mythology? Options: A. The return of Persephone to the underworld, B. The return of Persephone to the land of the living, C. The compromise made between Demeter and Zeus regarding Persephone's time in the underworld, D. The transit of Persephone between the underworld and the land of the living Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1: "Who was the goddess of agriculture in ancient Greek mythology?" 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to identify Demeter's role in Greek mythology. The options in Question 1 are also similar to the ground truth MCQ, with Demeter being the correct answer.
