Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
will russia go to war with ukraine all week you've heard numerous answers to this question in ukraine 71 of the people believe their country is already at war with russia this is a complex crisis and all the answers are hidden in history did you know there was a time when kier was more powerful than moscow there was also a time when ukraine and america were adversaries tonight we'll bring you all these stories we will tell you why russian president vladimir putin is obsessed with ukraine i'm palki sharma padhya and this is gravitas plus we begin in the ninth century there was a state called kevin ruse this is where it was located the slavic people lived here the city of kiev was their capital between 980 and 1015 the kevin ruse was ruled by grand prince volodymir in russian his name is vladimir in ukrainian volodymir and as fate would have it these are also the names of the presidents of these two countries today anyway russians ukrainians and better russians draw their lineage from this slavic state a lot changed in the centuries that followed and for a lot of it ukraine was under russian rule in the 1900s the two were soviet republics russia the most powerful of the 15 republics and ukraine the second most powerful it had defence industries large agricultural lands and housed much of the soviet nuclear arsenal during the cold war ukraine was the arch rival of the united states the soviet union collapsed in 1991 ukraine became independent as did russia ukraine inherited much of soviet nuclear arsenal but gave it up to russia in 1994. in exchange moscow guaranteed ukraine's security and promised to respect its sovereignty they signed the budapest memorandum along with these countries cut to november 2013 viktor yanukovych was the president of ukraine he had a reputation for heavy-handedness corruption and above all for being openly pro-moscow in 2013 he rejected an eu trade deal this deal could have meant greater integration with the european union instead yanukovych decided to take a 15 billion dollar bailout from russia to many ukrainians it felt like being sold to moscow so protests broke out they were called euromaidan euro because these protests were about europe and maidan because they happened in kiev's maidan what we today know as the independent square here protesters chanted signed the eu deal yanukovych must step down russia supported the president the west supported the protesters in february 2014 yanukovich's government was toppled the president was driven out of ukraine he fled to russia not every ukrainian was happy with this many in the russian speaking east wanted yanukovich to stay when he was driven out the minority felt disenfranchised on the other side of the border russia was angry it had lost its puppet to salvage the situation moscow annexed crimea why crimea well let's now zoom into this part of the world crimea is a peninsula it is located in the black sea in 1954 soviet leader nikita khrushchev transferred crimea it was given to the ukrainian soviet socialist republic from the russian soviet socialist republic why khrushchev hoped the transfer would strengthen quote unquote brotherly ties between the ukrainian and russian people both russia and crimea were part of the soviet union so this transfer did not mean very much when ukraine became independent in 1991 crimea joined it the peninsula was given special autonomy it remained home to russian military bases moscow promised to respect crimean autonomy many in russia were of the opinion that crimea should not have been allowed to join ukraine in 2014 when yanukovych was ousted from power in ukraine russian military began seizing government buildings in crimea so the entire peninsula was under military occupation a referendum followed on the 16th of march 2014 crimeans voted to become a part of russia was this vote legitimate well it depends on who you ask for putin this was crimea's liberation for the rest of the world this was crimea's annexation the focus then shifted to eastern ukraine where russia backed separatists had seized territory ukrainian forces did not launch an all-out offensive at first but on the 17th of july 2014 when a flight carrying 298 people were shot down by these rebels ukrainian forces decided to flush out the rebels the separatists began losing ground so the russian army stepped in they invaded eastern ukraine and fought alongside the rebels what followed was a series of talks between russia ukraine and the west they resulted in the minsk accords this was first signed in 2014 both sides agreed on ceasefire and military withdrawal ukraine agreed to hold elections in the rebel-held areas eight years on the minsk accords remain unimplemented ukraine stands as the largest european country excluding russia it covers an area of more than six hundred thousand square kilometers with a population of 44 million and a gdp of more than 155 billion dollars per capita income more than 3 700 today ukraine is divided between east and west in more ways than one the west sees itself as more european the east is closer to russia be it in terms of geography or sentiment in the west most ukrainians speak ukrainian in the east a third are native russians in the west russia is looked at with suspicion in the east russia is looked at through the lens of shared history and heritage ukraine also remains at war its forces are fighting the rebels in the east rebel leaders are ruling at least two regions donetsk and luansk together they're known as the donbass region russia has once again sent its troops this time they're stationed right at the border what does vladimir putin want for nato to stop expanding nato stands for north atlantic treaty organization it's a military alliance these countries are the founding members of nato these countries joined it during the cold war and these countries joined after it ukraine wants to join nato too but putin wants nato to exclude ukraine and every former soviet state and this is just half the story like i said a lot is hidden in history for starters there is domestic politics when putin annexed crimea his approval rating skyrocketed keeping the nationalistic drum rolling helps the russian president annexing parts of ukraine also helps putin restore russia's superpower image again back to history many russians view ukraine's independence as a mistake it is true that ukraine was ruled by russia in fact ukraine has barely remained independent pre-1991 there was a brief period before world war one and then another stint in 1600 for the rest of its modern history ukraine was under russia one in six ukrainians is an ethnic russian one in three speaks russian as a native language so putin is right when he says historically they were one but claiming ukraine on the basis of colonial history is wrong it will be like britain claiming india or south africa or spain claiming the philippines past imperialism cannot justify present-day expansionism here's what else history tells us ukraine was forcefully crucified cut to 1700 russian leader katherine the great started russifying ukraine ethnic russians were shipped to this part of the world schools were told to teach russian language by 1800 the ukrainian language was banned in 1930 soviet leader joseph stalin steered a famine in ukraine millions of eastern ukrainians were killed the area was then repopulated with ethnic russians in the 1940s the ethnic tartars were relocated they too were replaced with russians there is a reason why eastern ukraine today has so many native russian speakers it was designed to be that way eastern ukraine was always dear to russia it has coal it has iron fertile land its historical connection with russia was forced both in time and again talks about the holy ruse he says russians and ukrainians are one people seventy percent ukrainians reject this thought seventy two percent consider russia a hostile state today thirty three point three percent ukrainians are ready to take up arms against russia twenty one point seven percent are ready to stage a civil resistance against russia 67 percent ukrainians want to join the eu 59 percent want to join the nato meet the current ukrainian president volodymyr zielenski he came to power in 2019 following a landslide victory he is a vocal critic of russia zelensky openly opposes russian occupation of eastern ukraine 73 percent of ukrainian voters voted this man to power today volodymir zelensky represents the pulse of ukraine the ukraine that wants to remain independent of russia but vladimir putin wants to become the man who revived russian imperialism he does not realize the world has moved on [Music]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Between 980 and 1015, the Kievan Rus was ruled by:
Options: A. Catherine the Great, B. Grand Prince Volodimer , C. Nikita Khrushchev, D. Feodor III
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: **Knowledge** Options: A. Ukraine was under Russian rule from 1600 to 1991., B. Ukraine was under Russian rule from 1700 to 1991., C. Ukraine was under Russian rule from 1800 to 1991., D. Ukraine was under Russian rule from 1900 to 1991. Correct Option: D
Question 2: **Comprehension** Options: A. The Budapest Memorandum was signed by Ukraine, Russia, and the United States in 1994., B. The Budapest Memorandum was signed by Ukraine, Russia, and the European Union in 1994., C. The Budapest Memorandum was signed by Ukraine, Russia, and the United Nations in 1994., D. The Budapest Memorandum was signed by Ukraine, Russia, and the Soviet Union in 1994. Correct Option: A
Question 3: **Application** Options: A. If Ukraine joins NATO, Russia will not invade Ukraine., B. If Ukraine joins NATO, Russia will invade Ukraine., C. If Ukraine joins NATO, Russia will remain neutral., D. If Ukraine joins NATO, Russia will provide military aid to Ukraine. Correct Option: B
Question 4: **Analysis** Options: A. The annexation of Crimea by Russia was a legitimate move to protect the rights of ethnic Russians living there., B. The annexation of Crimea by Russia was a violation of Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity., C. The annexation of Crimea by Russia was a necessary step to secure Russia's strategic interests in the region., D. The annexation of Crimea by Russia was a surprise move that caught Ukraine off guard. Correct Option: B
Question 5: **Synthesis** Options: A. The conflict between Ukraine and Russia is a result of a long-standing historical feud between the two countries have been at odds since the 18th century., B. The conflict between Ukraine and Russia is a result of a combination of historical, cultural, and economic factors that have contributed to the current tensions., C. The conflict between Ukraine and Russia is a result of a single event, such as the annexation of Crimea, that sparked the current crisis., D. The conflict between Ukraine and Russia is a result of a simple misunderstanding between the two countries. Correct Option: B
Question 6: **Evaluation** Options: A. Vladimir Putin's decision to annex Crimea was a wise move that has strengthened Russia's position in the region., B. Vladimir Putin's decision to annex Crimea was a reckless move that has isolated Russia from the international community., C. Vladimir Putin's decision to annex Crimea was a necessary step to protect the rights of ethnic Russians living there., D. Vladimir Putin's decision to annex Crimea was a surprise move that caught Ukraine off guard. Correct Option: B
Question 7: **Knowledge** Options: A. Ukraine has a population of 50 million people., B. Ukraine has a population of 44 million people., C. Ukraine has a population of 40 million people., D. Ukraine has a population of 60 million people. Correct Option: B
Question 8: **Comprehension** Options: A. The Minsk Accords were signed by Ukraine, Russia, and the European Union in 2014., B. The Minsk Accords were signed by Ukraine, Russia, and the United Nations in 2014., C. The Minsk Accords were signed by Ukraine, Russia, and the United States in 2014., D. The Minsk Accords were signed by Ukraine, Russia, and the Soviet Union in 2014. Correct Option: A
Question 9: **Application** Options: A. If Ukraine joins the EU, Russia will not invade Ukraine., B. If Ukraine joins the EU, Russia will invade Ukraine., C. If Ukraine joins the EU, Russia will remain neutral., D. If Ukraine joins the EU, Russia will provide military aid to Ukraine. Correct Option: A
Question 10: **Analysis** Options: A. The conflict between Ukraine and Russia is a result of a simple misunderstanding between the two countries., B. The conflict between Ukraine and Russia is a result of a combination of historical, including historical, cultural, and economic factors that have contributed to the current tensions., C. The conflict between Ukraine and Russia is a result of a single event, such as the annexation of Crimea, that sparked the current crisis., D. The conflict between Ukraine and Russia is a result of a long-standing historical feud between the two countries. Correct Option: B

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Question: The Soviet Union collapsed in:
Options: A. 1994, B. 1981, C. 1991, D. 1989
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It’s moments after the Big Bang
and... wow, you’re still reeling. You’re a particle of matter, 
amidst a chaotic stew of forces, fusion, and annihilation. If you’re lucky
and avoid being destroyed by antimatter, you'll be the seed of a future galaxy. You gravitate towards a ring of particles
that have devised a game. A friendly gluon explains: there are an equal number of matter 
and antimatter particles. At the blow of a cosmic whistle, every particle of matter with a particle 
of antimatter to its immediate right will merge with that anitparticle
to—poof!— both annihilate. The circle will tighten 
to make a smaller circle, and the process will repeat 
until just one particle of matter remains. They’d been waiting for someone like you,
as with a perfectly balanced setup, no one would be left in the end. As guest of honor, they’ll let you choose 
where to insert yourself into the ring. What spot should you choose to make sure
you’re the last particle standing? Pause here if you want 
to figure it out for yourself. Explanation in 3 Explanation in 2 Explanation in 1 A general strategy can’t rely on knowing
what the circle looks like. But we can rely on how it should end: 
with you as the last particle standing. Let's start there and work backwards. Just before this, there were also 
some matter/antimatter pairs. Here’s 3 for the sake of example. This right away suggests a strategy. You can simulate annihilations 
in any circle by marking all pairs 
of adjacent particles, then the newly adjacent pairs, and so on,
to reach this final set. If you map them back 
to the original circle, standing to the immediate left 
of those final matter particles or the immediate right 
of final antiparticles means you’ll reach this endgame state 
and survive. So here are the safe spots 
in all three given circles. You find a good position and experience
the bittersweet radiance of your new friends pairing off
and becoming pure energy. You’re soon left alone. But wait a minute! Today’s the big day. You’re an intelligent creature of matter
amidst a chaotic crowd of alien races. Every hundred million years, sentient species of the galaxy 
send emissaries to the core to pay tribute to the galactic seed 
you’re all descended from. Each of the 27,182 attendees has brought a cube of matter 
and a cube of antimatter. Except you: you’ve been chosen 
to represent your famed ancestor and reenact its moment of choice. Everyone places their matter 
and antimatter cubes in a ring. Your job: pick a spot to stand 
where you won’t be annihilated. The ring is too large to simulate
annihilations like before, but you have a programmable device
you can point at spots between cubes. The device can detect the full sequence
of cubes around the circle, count cubes of each type,
perform arithmetic, and carry out simple logical commands. How do you program your device 
to identify safe spots? Pause to figure it out for yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 Let’s go back to our earlier approach: running time backwards 
starting from you alone, then a sequence of pairs of cubes. A second step back produces more pairs
nestled between existing cubes. As does the next, and the next,
each adding nestled pairs like a Russian doll 
of fundamental particles. A pair never forms around an existing cube
because only adjacent cubes annihilate. Your survival depends 
on the matter particles to your right buffering you from antimatter. We can mathematically model this idea 
with a sum, starting with your +1. For instance, this would be +1+1-1+1-1. From your perspective, 
no matter how far you look, this sum will be positive. Considering how we introduced pairs, 
this makes sense— each inserted plus was immediately
followed by a minus. If we examine the starting position
of any other matter cube, its sum will eventually hit zero. The moment that happens 
marks its exact annihilation partner. Again, our introduction of pairs 
reflects this; nestled pairs only delay the inevitable
for the outer cubes. We can now program the device. Start a running sum with +1,
representing you, and scan around the circle. For each matter cube, add one, and for each antimatter cube, 
subtract one. If all 54,364 cubes have been scanned without the sum ever hitting 0, that spot is safe. Nothing left to do 
but enjoy the fireworks.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Could four particles of matter and four particles of antimatter arrange themselves in a ring to provide you four different safe places to stand?
Options: A. Yes, B. No
Correct Option: A

Question 3: **Application**: If you were to insert yourself into the ring, where should you stand to make sure you're the last particle standing? Options: A. To the immediate left of a matter particle, B. To the immediate right of an antimatter particle, C. Between two matter particles, D. Between two antimatter particles Correct Option: B
Question 4: **Analysis**: What is the relationship between the number of matter particles and antimatter particles in the ring? Options: A. There are more matter particles than antimatter particles, B. There are an equal number of matter and antimatter particles, C. There are fewer antimatter particles than matter particles, D. There are no antimatter particles Correct Option: B
Question 5: **Synthesis**: How can you use the programmable device to identify safe spots in the ring? Options: A. By scanning the ring and counting the number of matter and antimatter particles, B. By starting a running sum with +1 and scanning around the circle, C. By analyzing the sequence of cubes around the circle, D. By using a complex algorithm Correct Option: B
Question 6: **Evaluation**: What is the advantage of using the programmable device to identify safe spots? Options: A. It is faster than scanning the ring manually, B. It is more accurate than analyzing the sequence of cubes, C. It allows you to consider the full sequence of cubes around the circle, D. It is more complicated than other methods Correct Option: C
Question 7: **Knowledge**: What is the purpose of the emissaries sent to the core by sentient species every hundred million years? Options: A. To pay tribute to the galactic seed, B. To form a new galaxy, C. To destroy a particle, D. To create a new star Correct Option: A

It is a crucial event in the formation of the galaxy, C. It is a event that determines the fate of the galaxy, D. It is a event that is forgotten Correct Option: C
Question 9: **Application**: How can you use the programmable device to simulate annihilations in the ring? Options: A. By scanning the ring and counting the number of matter and antimatter particles, B. By starting a running sum with +1 and scanning around the circle, C. By analyzing the sequence of cubes around the circle, D. By using a complex algorithm Correct Option: B
Question 10: **Analysis**: What is the relationship between the sum of the matter particles and the fate of the antimatter particles in the ring? Options: A. The sum determines the fate of the antimatter particles, B. The sum is unrelated to the fate of the antimatter particles, C. The sum is a indicator of the number of antimatter particles, D. The sum is a indicator of the number of matter particles Correct Option: A

to figure it out for yourself. Explanation in 3 Explanation in 2 Explanation in 1 A general strategy can’t rely on knowing
what the circle looks like. But we can rely on how it should end: 
with you as the last particle standing. Let's start there and work backwards. Just before this, there were also 
some matter/antimatter pairs. Here’s 3 for the sake of example. This right away suggests a strategy. You can simulate annihilations 
in any circle by marking all pairs 
of adjacent particles, then the newly adjacent pairs, and so on,
to reach this final set. If you map them back 
to the original circle, standing to the immediate left 
of those final matter particles or the immediate right 
of final antiparticles means you’ll reach this endgame state 
and survive. So here are the safe spots 
in all three given circles. You find a good position and experience
the bittersweet radiance of your new friends pairing off
and becoming pure energy. You’re soon left alone. But wait a minute! Today’s the big day. You’re an intelligent creature of matter
amidst a chaotic crowd of alien races. Every hundred million years, sentient species of the galaxy 
send emissaries to the core to pay tribute to the galactic seed 
you’re all descended from. Each of the 27,182 attendees has brought a cube of matter 
and a cube of antimatter. Except you: you’ve been chosen 
to represent your famed ancestor and reenact its moment of choice. Everyone places their matter 
and antimatter cubes in a ring. Your job: pick a spot to stand 
where you won’t be annihilated. The ring is too large to simulate
annihilations like before, but you have a programmable device
you can point at spots between cubes. The device can detect the full sequence
of cubes around the circle, count cubes of each type,
perform arithmetic, and carry out simple logical commands. How do you program your device 
to identify safe spots? Pause to figure it out for yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 Let’s go back to our earlier approach: running time backwards 
starting from you alone, then a sequence of pairs of cubes. A second step back produces more pairs
nestled between existing cubes. As does the next, and the next,
each adding nestled pairs like a Russian doll 
of fundamental particles. A pair never forms around an existing cube
because only adjacent cubes annihilate. Your survival depends 
on the matter particles to your right buffering you from antimatter. We can mathematically model this idea 
with a sum, starting with your +1. For instance, this would be +1+1-1+1-1. From your perspective, 
no matter how far you look, this sum will be positive. Considering how we introduced pairs, 
this makes sense— each inserted plus was immediately
followed by a minus. If we examine the starting position
of any other matter cube, its sum will eventually hit zero. The moment that happens 
marks its exact annihilation partner. Again, our introduction of pairs 
reflects this; nestled pairs only delay the inevitable
for the outer cubes. We can now program the device. Start a running sum with +1,
representing you, and scan around the circle. For each matter cube, add one, and for each antimatter cube, 
subtract one. If all 54,364 cubes have been scanned without the sum ever hitting 0, that spot is safe. Nothing left to do 
but enjoy the fireworks.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Could four particles of matter and four particles of antimatter arrange themselves in a ring to provide you just one safe place to stand?
Options: A. Yes, B. No
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: **Knowledge**: What is the Big Bang? Options: A. The explosion of a star, B. The formation of a new galaxy, C. The origin of the universe, D. The collision of two planets Correct Option: C
Question 2: **Comprehension**: What is the goal of the game played by the particles in the ring? Options: A. To create a new particle, B. To destroy a particle, C. To make sure only one particle remains, D. To form a new galaxy Correct Option: C
Question 3: **Application**: If you were to insert yourself into the ring, where should you stand to make sure you're the last particle standing? Options: A. To the immediate left of a matter particle, B. To the immediate right of an antimatter particle, C. Between two matter particles, D. Between two antimatter particles Correct Option: B
Question 4: **Analysis**: What is the relationship between the number of matter particles and antimatter particles in the ring? Options: A. There are more matter particles than antimatter particles, B. There are an equal number of matter and antimatter particles, C. There are fewer antimatter particles than matter particles, D. There are no antimatter particles Correct Option: B
Question 5: **Synthesis**: How can you use the programmable device to identify safe spots in the ring? Options: A. By scanning the ring and counting the number of matter and antimatter particles, B. By starting a running sum with +1 and scanning around the circle, C. By analyzing the sequence of cubes around the circle, D. By using a complex algorithm Correct Option: B
Question 6: **Evaluation**: What is the advantage of using the programmable device to identify safe spots? Options: A. It is faster than scanning the ring manually, B. It is more accurate than analyzing the sequence of cubes, C. It allows you to consider the full sequence of cubes around the circle, D. It is more complicated than other methods Correct Option: C
Question 7: **Knowledge**: What is the purpose of the emissaries sent to the core by sentient species every hundred million years? Options: A. To pay tribute to the galactic seed, B. To form a new galaxy, C. To destroy a particle, D. To create a new star Correct Option: A
Question 8: **Comprehension**: What is the significance of the moment of choice made by the ancestor of the sentient species? Options: A. It is a random event, B. It is a crucial event in the formation of the galaxy, C. It is a event that determines the fate of the galaxy, D. It is a event that is forgotten Correct Option: C
Question 9: **Application**: How can you use the programmable device to simulate annihilations in the ring? Options: A. By scanning the ring and counting the number of matter and antimatter particles, B. By starting a running sum with +1 and scanning around the circle, C. By analyzing the sequence of cubes around the circle, D. By using a complex algorithm Correct Option: B
Question 10: **Analysis**: What is the relationship between the sum of the matter particles and the fate of the antimatter particles in the ring? Options: A. The sum determines the fate of the antimatter particles, B. The sum is unrelated to the fate of the antimatter particles, C. The sum is a indicator of the number of antimatter particles, D. The sum is a indicator of the number of matter particles Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

There are more matter particles than antimatter particles, B. There are an equal number of matter and antimatter particles, C. There are fewer antimatter particles than matter particles, D. There are no antimatter particles Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It’s moments after the Big Bang
and... wow, you’re still reeling. You’re a particle of matter, 
amidst a chaotic stew of forces, fusion, and annihilation. If you’re lucky
and avoid being destroyed by antimatter, you'll be the seed of a future galaxy. You gravitate towards a ring of particles
that have devised a game. A friendly gluon explains: there are an equal number of matter 
and antimatter particles. At the blow of a cosmic whistle, every particle of matter with a particle 
of antimatter to its immediate right will merge with that anitparticle
to—poof!— both annihilate. The circle will tighten 
to make a smaller circle, and the process will repeat 
until just one particle of matter remains. They’d been waiting for someone like you,
as with a perfectly balanced setup, no one would be left in the end. As guest of honor, they’ll let you choose 
where to insert yourself into the ring. What spot should you choose to make sure
you’re the last particle standing? Pause here if you want 
to figure it out for yourself. Explanation in 3 Explanation in 2 Explanation in 1 A general strategy can’t rely on knowing
what the circle looks like. But we can rely on how it should end: 
with you as the last particle standing. Let's start there and work backwards. Just before this, there were also 
some matter/antimatter pairs. Here’s 3 for the sake of example. This right away suggests a strategy. You can simulate annihilations 
in any circle by marking all pairs 
of adjacent particles, then the newly adjacent pairs, and so on,
to reach this final set. If you map them back 
to the original circle, standing to the immediate left 
of those final matter particles or the immediate right 
of final antiparticles means you’ll reach this endgame state 
and survive. So here are the safe spots 
in all three given circles. You find a good position and experience
the bittersweet radiance of your new friends pairing off
and becoming pure energy. You’re soon left alone. But wait a minute! Today’s the big day. You’re an intelligent creature of matter
amidst a chaotic crowd of alien races. Every hundred million years, sentient species of the galaxy 
send emissaries to the core to pay tribute to the galactic seed 
you’re all descended from. Each of the 27,182 attendees has brought a cube of matter 
and a cube of antimatter. Except you: you’ve been chosen 
to represent your famed ancestor and reenact its moment of choice. Everyone places their matter 
and antimatter cubes in a ring. Your job: pick a spot to stand 
where you won’t be annihilated. The ring is too large to simulate
annihilations like before, but you have a programmable device
you can point at spots between cubes. The device can detect the full sequence
of cubes around the circle, count cubes of each type,
perform arithmetic, and carry out simple logical commands. How do you program your device 
to identify safe spots? Pause to figure it out for yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 Let’s go back to our earlier approach: running time backwards 
starting from you alone, then a sequence of pairs of cubes. A second step back produces more pairs
nestled between existing cubes. As does the next, and the next,
each adding nestled pairs like a Russian doll 
of fundamental particles. A pair never forms around an existing cube
because only adjacent cubes annihilate. Your survival depends 
on the matter particles to your right buffering you from antimatter. We can mathematically model this idea 
with a sum, starting with your +1. For instance, this would be +1+1-1+1-1. From your perspective, 
no matter how far you look, this sum will be positive. Considering how we introduced pairs, 
this makes sense— each inserted plus was immediately
followed by a minus. If we examine the starting position
of any other matter cube, its sum will eventually hit zero. The moment that happens 
marks its exact annihilation partner. Again, our introduction of pairs 
reflects this; nestled pairs only delay the inevitable
for the outer cubes. We can now program the device. Start a running sum with +1,
representing you, and scan around the circle. For each matter cube, add one, and for each antimatter cube, 
subtract one. If all 54,364 cubes have been scanned without the sum ever hitting 0, that spot is safe. Nothing left to do 
but enjoy the fireworks.

to—poof!— both annihilate. The circle will tighten 
to make a smaller circle, and the process will repeat 
until just one particle of matter remains. They’d been waiting for someone like you,

you’re the last particle standing? Pause here if you want 
to figure it out for yourself. Explanation in 3 Explanation in 2 Explanation in 1 A general strategy can’t rely on knowing

Question 7: **Knowledge**: What is the purpose of the emissaries sent to the core by sentient species every hundred million years? Options: A. To pay tribute to the galactic seed, B. To form a new galaxy, C. To destroy a particle, D. To create a new star Correct Option: A
Question 8: **Comprehension**: What is the significance of the moment of choice made by the ancestor of the sentient species? Options: A. It is a random event, B. It is a crucial event in the formation of the galaxy, C. It is a event that determines the fate of the galaxy, D. It is a event that is forgotten Correct Option: C
Question 9: **Application**: How can you use the programmable device to simulate annihilations in the ring? Options: A. By scanning the ring and counting the number of matter and antimatter particles, B. By starting a running sum with +1 and scanning around the circle, C. By analyzing the sequence of cubes around the circle, D. By using a complex algorithm Correct Option: B
Question 10: **Analysis**: What is the relationship between the sum of the matter particles and the fate of the antimatter particles in the ring? Options: A. The sum determines the fate of the antimatter particles, B. The sum is unrelated to the fate of the antimatter particles, C. The sum is a indicator of the number of antimatter particles, D. The sum is a indicator of the number of matter particles Correct Option: A

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It’s moments after the Big Bang
and... wow, you’re still reeling. You’re a particle of matter, 
amidst a chaotic stew of forces, fusion, and annihilation. If you’re lucky
and avoid being destroyed by antimatter, you'll be the seed of a future galaxy. You gravitate towards a ring of particles
that have devised a game. A friendly gluon explains: there are an equal number of matter 
and antimatter particles. At the blow of a cosmic whistle, every particle of matter with a particle 
of antimatter to its immediate right will merge with that anitparticle
to—poof!— both annihilate. The circle will tighten 
to make a smaller circle, and the process will repeat 
until just one particle of matter remains. They’d been waiting for someone like you,
as with a perfectly balanced setup, no one would be left in the end. As guest of honor, they’ll let you choose 
where to insert yourself into the ring. What spot should you choose to make sure
you’re the last particle standing? Pause here if you want 
to figure it out for yourself. Explanation in 3 Explanation in 2 Explanation in 1 A general strategy can’t rely on knowing
what the circle looks like. But we can rely on how it should end: 
with you as the last particle standing. Let's start there and work backwards. Just before this, there were also 
some matter/antimatter pairs. Here’s 3 for the sake of example. This right away suggests a strategy. You can simulate annihilations 
in any circle by marking all pairs 
of adjacent particles, then the newly adjacent pairs, and so on,
to reach this final set. If you map them back 
to the original circle, standing to the immediate left 
of those final matter particles or the immediate right 
of final antiparticles means you’ll reach this endgame state 
and survive. So here are the safe spots 
in all three given circles. You find a good position and experience
the bittersweet radiance of your new friends pairing off
and becoming pure energy. You’re soon left alone. But wait a minute! Today’s the big day. You’re an intelligent creature of matter
amidst a chaotic crowd of alien races. Every hundred million years, sentient species of the galaxy 
send emissaries to the core to pay tribute to the galactic seed 
you’re all descended from. Each of the 27,182 attendees has brought a cube of matter 
and a cube of antimatter. Except you: you’ve been chosen 
to represent your famed ancestor and reenact its moment of choice. Everyone places their matter 
and antimatter cubes in a ring. Your job: pick a spot to stand 
where you won’t be annihilated. The ring is too large to simulate
annihilations like before, but you have a programmable device
you can point at spots between cubes. The device can detect the full sequence
of cubes around the circle, count cubes of each type,
perform arithmetic, and carry out simple logical commands. How do you program your device 
to identify safe spots? Pause to figure it out for yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 Let’s go back to our earlier approach: running time backwards 
starting from you alone, then a sequence of pairs of cubes. A second step back produces more pairs
nestled between existing cubes. As does the next, and the next,
each adding nestled pairs like a Russian doll 
of fundamental particles. A pair never forms around an existing cube
because only adjacent cubes annihilate. Your survival depends 
on the matter particles to your right buffering you from antimatter. We can mathematically model this idea 
with a sum, starting with your +1. For instance, this would be +1+1-1+1-1. From your perspective, 
no matter how far you look, this sum will be positive. Considering how we introduced pairs, 
this makes sense— each inserted plus was immediately
followed by a minus. If we examine the starting position
of any other matter cube, its sum will eventually hit zero. The moment that happens 
marks its exact annihilation partner. Again, our introduction of pairs 
reflects this; nestled pairs only delay the inevitable
for the outer cubes. We can now program the device. Start a running sum with +1,
representing you, and scan around the circle. For each matter cube, add one, and for each antimatter cube, 
subtract one. If all 54,364 cubes have been scanned without the sum ever hitting 0, that spot is safe. Nothing left to do 
but enjoy the fireworks.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Eight particles of matter and six particles of antimatter are arranged in a ring and play the same annihilation game. How many particles of matter will remain at the end of the game?
Options: A. 0, B. 1, C. 2, D. More than 2
Correct Option: C

Options: A. Yes! All three, for sure, will survive., B. Maybe. It depends on the ring pattern., C. Not all three will survive.
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the mid-1930s, two familiar spires
towered above the morning fog. Stretching 227 meters into the sky, these 22,000-ton towers would help support
California’s Golden Gate Bridge. But since they were currently
in Pennsylvania, they first had to be dismantled,
packaged, and shipped piece by piece over 4,500 kilometers away. Moving the bridge’s towers 
across a continent was just one of the challenges 
facing Charles Ellis and Joseph Strauss, the project's lead engineers. Even before construction began, 
the pair faced all kinds of opposition. The military feared the bridge 
would make the important harbor an even more vulnerable target. Ferry companies claimed the bridge
would steal their business, and residents wanted to preserve
the area's natural scenery. Worse still, many engineers thought
the project was impossible. The Golden Gate Strait was home 
to 96-kilometer-per-hour winds, swirling tides, an endless blanket of fog, and the earthquake-prone 
San Andreas fault. But Strauss was convinced 
the bridge could be built; and that it would provide 
San Francisco’s commuters more reliable passage to the city. He was, however, a bit out of his depth. Strauss’s initial plans to span the strait
used a cantilever bridge. This kind of bridge consists 
of a single beam anchored at one end and extended horizontally
like a diving board. Since these bridges can only extend so far
before collapsing under their own weight, Strauss’s design used two cantilevers,
linked by a structure in the middle. But Ellis and his colleague Leon Moisseif
convinced Strauss to pursue a different approach:
the suspension bridge. Where a cantilever bridge is supported
from one end a suspension bridge suspends its deck
from cables strung across the gap. The result is a more flexible structure that’s resilient to winds 
and shifting loads. This kind of design had long been used 
for small rope bridges. And in the 1930s, 
advanced steel manufacturing could create cables of bundled wire 
to act as strong steel rope for large-scale construction. At the time, the Golden Gate Bridge was the longest and tallest 
suspension bridge ever attempted, and its design was only possible
due to these innovations. But cables and towers of this size 
could only be built at large steelworks on the country’s east coast. While the recently completed Panama Canal made it possible to ship these components
to California, reassembling the towers on site 
didn’t go quite as smoothly. It was relatively easy to find a stable,
shallow foundation for the north tower. But building the south tower 
essentially required erecting a ten-story building underwater. Since the strait’s depth prevented them
drilling or digging the foundations, bombs were dropped on the ocean floor,
creating openings for pouring concrete. A seawall was built to protect the site
from powerful currents, and workers operated in 20-minute shifts
between tides. The towers had so many compartments
that each worker carried a set of plans to prevent getting lost. And at one point, an earthquake rocked
the south tower nearly 5 meters in each direction. Strauss took worker safety very seriously,
requiring hard hats at all times and stretching a safety net 
below the towers. But not even these precautions 
could prevent an entire scaffolding platform
from falling in 1937, carrying ten workers to their deaths. Once the towers were complete, 
workers spun the cables in place, hung suspenders at 50-foot intervals,
and laid down the concrete roadway. The bridge was finished,
but there was still one more task ahead: painting it. After production, the steel had been 
coated with a reddish paint primer it maintained throughout construction. But the Navy had been pushing hard to paint the bridge 
a tactical black and yellow. Consulting architect Irving Morrow 
actually thought the primer itself paired nicely with the strait’s 
natural backdrop— and he wasn’t alone. Citing numerous letters from locals, Morrow’s 30-page pitch 
to paint the bridge “international orange” beat out the Navy’s plans. And today, this iconic color 
still complements the strait’s blue water, green hills, 
and rolling fog.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of these was NOT one of the structural difficulties of building a bridge across the Golden Gate?
Options: A. Impenetrable bedrock, B. Earthquakes, C. Strong winds and tides
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the approximate weight of the Golden Gate Bridge's towers? Options: A. 10,000 tons, B. 20,000 tons, C. 22,000 tons, D. 30,000 tons Correct Option: C
Question 2: Which of the following was a major challenge faced by Charles Ellis and Joseph Strauss when building the Golden Gate Bridge? Options: A. The bridge's design was too complex, B. The military feared the bridge would make the harbor an even more vulnerable target, C. The bridge's construction was too expensive, D. The bridge's builders were inexperienced Correct Option: B
Question 3: What type of bridge was initially proposed by Joseph Strauss for the Golden Gate Bridge? Options: A. Suspension bridge, B. Cantilever bridge, C. Arch bridge, D. Beam bridge Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the main advantage of using a suspension bridge design for the Golden Gate Bridge? Options: A. It was cheaper to build, B. It was more resistant to strong winds and shifting loads, C. It was easier to construct, D. It was more aesthetically pleasing Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the main reason why the cables and towers of the Golden Gate Bridge had to be built on the east coast before being shipped to California? Options: A. The east coast had better steel manufacturing facilities, B. The east coast had more experienced engineers, C. The east coast had larger steelworks, D. The east coast had better transportation infrastructure Correct Option: C
Question 6: How did the builders of the Golden Gate Bridge create openings for pouring concrete to build the south tower? Options: A. They drilled or dug the foundations, B. They built a seawall to protect the site from powerful currents, C. They dropped bombs on the ocean floor, D. They used a crane to lift the concrete into place Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the main reason why the Navy wanted to paint the Golden Gate Bridge a tactical black and yellow? Options: A. To make it more visible to ships, B. To make it more resistant to corrosion, C. To make it more attractive to tourists, D. To make it more difficult for enemy aircraft to spot Correct Option: D
Question 8: Who was the consulting architect who argued that the Golden Gate Bridge should be painted "international orange"? Options: A. Irving Morrow, B. Joseph Strauss, C. Charles Ellis, D. Leon Moisseif Correct Option: A
Question 9: What was the result of the earthquake that rocked the south tower nearly 5 meters in each direction? Options: A. The tower collapsed, B. The tower was severely damaged, C. The tower was slightly damaged, D. The earthquake had no effect on the tower Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the main reason why Irving Morrow's proposal to paint the Golden Gate Bridge "international orange" was accepted? Options: A. It was cheaper than the Navy's proposal, B. It was more aesthetically pleasing, C. It was supported by numerous letters from locals, D. It was a compromise between the Navy's proposal and the consulting architect's proposal Correct Option: C

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the mid-1930s, two familiar spires
towered above the morning fog. Stretching 227 meters into the sky, these 22,000-ton towers would help support
California’s Golden Gate Bridge. But since they were currently
in Pennsylvania, they first had to be dismantled,
packaged, and shipped piece by piece over 4,500 kilometers away. Moving the bridge’s towers 
across a continent was just one of the challenges 
facing Charles Ellis and Joseph Strauss, the project's lead engineers. Even before construction began, 
the pair faced all kinds of opposition. The military feared the bridge 
would make the important harbor an even more vulnerable target. Ferry companies claimed the bridge
would steal their business, and residents wanted to preserve
the area's natural scenery. Worse still, many engineers thought
the project was impossible. The Golden Gate Strait was home 
to 96-kilometer-per-hour winds, swirling tides, an endless blanket of fog, and the earthquake-prone 
San Andreas fault. But Strauss was convinced 
the bridge could be built; and that it would provide 
San Francisco’s commuters more reliable passage to the city. He was, however, a bit out of his depth. Strauss’s initial plans to span the strait
used a cantilever bridge. This kind of bridge consists 
of a single beam anchored at one end and extended horizontally
like a diving board. Since these bridges can only extend so far
before collapsing under their own weight, Strauss’s design used two cantilevers,
linked by a structure in the middle. But Ellis and his colleague Leon Moisseif
convinced Strauss to pursue a different approach:
the suspension bridge. Where a cantilever bridge is supported
from one end a suspension bridge suspends its deck
from cables strung across the gap. The result is a more flexible structure that’s resilient to winds 
and shifting loads. This kind of design had long been used 
for small rope bridges. And in the 1930s, 
advanced steel manufacturing could create cables of bundled wire 
to act as strong steel rope for large-scale construction. At the time, the Golden Gate Bridge was the longest and tallest 
suspension bridge ever attempted, and its design was only possible
due to these innovations. But cables and towers of this size 
could only be built at large steelworks on the country’s east coast. While the recently completed Panama Canal made it possible to ship these components
to California, reassembling the towers on site 
didn’t go quite as smoothly. It was relatively easy to find a stable,
shallow foundation for the north tower. But building the south tower 
essentially required erecting a ten-story building underwater. Since the strait’s depth prevented them
drilling or digging the foundations, bombs were dropped on the ocean floor,
creating openings for pouring concrete. A seawall was built to protect the site
from powerful currents, and workers operated in 20-minute shifts
between tides. The towers had so many compartments
that each worker carried a set of plans to prevent getting lost. And at one point, an earthquake rocked
the south tower nearly 5 meters in each direction. Strauss took worker safety very seriously,
requiring hard hats at all times and stretching a safety net 
below the towers. But not even these precautions 
could prevent an entire scaffolding platform
from falling in 1937, carrying ten workers to their deaths. Once the towers were complete, 
workers spun the cables in place, hung suspenders at 50-foot intervals,
and laid down the concrete roadway. The bridge was finished,
but there was still one more task ahead: painting it. After production, the steel had been 
coated with a reddish paint primer it maintained throughout construction. But the Navy had been pushing hard to paint the bridge 
a tactical black and yellow. Consulting architect Irving Morrow 
actually thought the primer itself paired nicely with the strait’s 
natural backdrop— and he wasn’t alone. Citing numerous letters from locals, Morrow’s 30-page pitch 
to paint the bridge “international orange” beat out the Navy’s plans. And today, this iconic color 
still complements the strait’s blue water, green hills, 
and rolling fog.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of these was NOT one of the arguments against the bridge’s construction?
Options: A. Security concerns from the military, B. Ferry companies fearing competition, C. Disruption of wildlife habitats
Correct Option: C

Question 5: What was the main reason why the cables and towers of the Golden Gate Bridge had to be built on the east coast before being shipped to California? Options: A. The east coast had better steel manufacturing facilities, B. The east coast had more experienced engineers, C. The east coast had larger steelworks, D. The east coast had better transportation infrastructure Correct Option: C
Question 6: How did the builders of the Golden Gate Bridge create openings for pouring concrete to build the south tower? Options: A. They drilled or dug the foundations, B. They built a seawall to protect the site from powerful currents, C. They dropped bombs on the ocean floor, D. They used a crane to lift the concrete into place Correct Option: C

Question 8: Who was the consulting architect who argued that the Golden Gate Bridge should be painted "international orange"? Options: A. Irving Morrow, B. Joseph Strauss, C. Charles Ellis, D. Leon Moisseif Correct Option: A
Question 9: What was the result of the earthquake that rocked the south tower nearly 5 meters in each direction? Options: A. The tower collapsed, B. The tower was severely damaged, C. The tower was slightly damaged, D. The earthquake had no effect on the tower Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the main reason why Irving Morrow's proposal to paint the Golden Gate Bridge "international orange" was accepted? Options: A. It was cheaper than the Navy's proposal, B. It was more aesthetically pleasing, C. It was supported by numerous letters from locals, D. It was a compromise between the Navy's proposal and the consulting architect's proposal Correct Option: C

to act as strong steel rope for large-scale construction. At the time, the Golden Gate Bridge was the longest and tallest

due to these innovations. But cables and towers of this size

a tactical black and yellow. Consulting architect Irving Morrow 
actually thought the primer itself paired nicely with the strait’s 
natural backdrop— and he wasn’t alone. Citing numerous letters from locals, Morrow’s 30-page pitch 
to paint the bridge “international orange” beat out the Navy’s plans. And today, this iconic color 
still complements the strait’s blue water, green hills, 
and rolling fog.

In the mid-1930s, two familiar spires
towered above the morning fog. Stretching 227 meters into the sky, these 22,000-ton towers would help support
California’s Golden Gate Bridge. But since they were currently
in Pennsylvania, they first had to be dismantled,
packaged, and shipped piece by piece over 4,500 kilometers away. Moving the bridge’s towers 
across a continent was just one of the challenges 
facing Charles Ellis and Joseph Strauss, the project's lead engineers. Even before construction began, 
the pair faced all kinds of opposition. The military feared the bridge 
would make the important harbor an even more vulnerable target. Ferry companies claimed the bridge
would steal their business, and residents wanted to preserve
the area's natural scenery. Worse still, many engineers thought
the project was impossible. The Golden Gate Strait was home 
to 96-kilometer-per-hour winds, swirling tides, an endless blanket of fog, and the earthquake-prone 
San Andreas fault. But Strauss was convinced 
the bridge could be built; and that it would provide 
San Francisco’s commuters more reliable passage to the city. He was, however, a bit out of his depth. Strauss’s initial plans to span the strait
used a cantilever bridge. This kind of bridge consists 
of a single beam anchored at one end and extended horizontally
like a diving board. Since these bridges can only extend so far
before collapsing under their own weight, Strauss’s design used two cantilevers,
linked by a structure in the middle. But Ellis and his colleague Leon Moisseif
convinced Strauss to pursue a different approach:
the suspension bridge. Where a cantilever bridge is supported
from one end a suspension bridge suspends its deck
from cables strung across the gap. The result is a more flexible structure that’s resilient to winds 
and shifting loads. This kind of design had long been used 
for small rope bridges. And in the 1930s, 
advanced steel manufacturing could create cables of bundled wire 
to act as strong steel rope for large-scale construction. At the time, the Golden Gate Bridge was the longest and tallest 
suspension bridge ever attempted, and its design was only possible
due to these innovations. But cables and towers of this size 
could only be built at large steelworks on the country’s east coast. While the recently completed Panama Canal made it possible to ship these components
to California, reassembling the towers on site 
didn’t go quite as smoothly. It was relatively easy to find a stable,
shallow foundation for the north tower. But building the south tower 
essentially required erecting a ten-story building underwater. Since the strait’s depth prevented them
drilling or digging the foundations, bombs were dropped on the ocean floor,
creating openings for pouring concrete. A seawall was built to protect the site
from powerful currents, and workers operated in 20-minute shifts
between tides. The towers had so many compartments
that each worker carried a set of plans to prevent getting lost. And at one point, an earthquake rocked
the south tower nearly 5 meters in each direction. Strauss took worker safety very seriously,
requiring hard hats at all times and stretching a safety net 
below the towers. But not even these precautions 
could prevent an entire scaffolding platform
from falling in 1937, carrying ten workers to their deaths. Once the towers were complete, 
workers spun the cables in place, hung suspenders at 50-foot intervals,
and laid down the concrete roadway. The bridge was finished,
but there was still one more task ahead: painting it. After production, the steel had been 
coated with a reddish paint primer it maintained throughout construction. But the Navy had been pushing hard to paint the bridge 
a tactical black and yellow. Consulting architect Irving Morrow 
actually thought the primer itself paired nicely with the strait’s 
natural backdrop— and he wasn’t alone. Citing numerous letters from locals, Morrow’s 30-page pitch 
to paint the bridge “international orange” beat out the Navy’s plans. And today, this iconic color 
still complements the strait’s blue water, green hills, 
and rolling fog.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When was the bridge completed?
Options: A. 1937, B. 1929, C. 1943
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the approximate weight of the Golden Gate Bridge's towers? Options: A. 10,000 tons, B. 20,000 tons, C. 22,000 tons, D. 30,000 tons Correct Option: C
Question 2: Which of the following was a major challenge faced by Charles Ellis and Joseph Strauss when building the Golden Gate Bridge? Options: A. The bridge's design was too complex, B. The military feared the bridge would make the harbor an even more vulnerable target, C. The bridge's construction was too expensive, D. The bridge's builders were inexperienced Correct Option: B
Question 3: What type of bridge was initially proposed by Joseph Strauss for the Golden Gate Bridge? Options: A. Suspension bridge, B. Cantilever bridge, C. Arch bridge, D. Beam bridge Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the main advantage of using a suspension bridge design for the Golden Gate Bridge? Options: A. It was cheaper to build, B. It was more resistant to strong winds and shifting loads, C. It was easier to construct, D. It was more aesthetically pleasing Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the main reason why the cables and towers of the Golden Gate Bridge had to be built on the east coast before being shipped to California? Options: A. The east coast had better steel manufacturing facilities, B. The east coast had more experienced engineers, C. The east coast had larger steelworks, D. The east coast had better transportation infrastructure Correct Option: C
Question 6: How did the builders of the Golden Gate Bridge create openings for pouring concrete to build the south tower? Options: A. They drilled or dug the foundations, B. They built a seawall to protect the site from powerful currents, C. They dropped bombs on the ocean floor, D. They used a crane to lift the concrete into place Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the main reason why the Navy wanted to paint the Golden Gate Bridge a tactical black and yellow? Options: A. To make it more visible to ships, B. To make it more resistant to corrosion, C. To make it more attractive to tourists, D. To make it more difficult for enemy aircraft to spot Correct Option: D
Question 8: Who was the consulting architect who argued that the Golden Gate Bridge should be painted "international orange"? Options: A. Irving Morrow, B. Joseph Strauss, C. Charles Ellis, D. Leon Moisseif Correct Option: A
Question 9: What was the result of the earthquake that rocked the south tower nearly 5 meters in each direction? Options: A. The tower collapsed, B. The tower was severely damaged, C. The tower was slightly damaged, D. The earthquake had no effect on the tower Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the main reason why Irving Morrow's proposal to paint the Golden Gate Bridge "international orange" was accepted? Options: A. It was cheaper than the Navy's proposal, B. It was more aesthetically pleasing, C. It was supported by numerous letters from locals, D. It was a compromise between the Navy's proposal and the consulting architect's proposal Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Hera, queen of the gods, 
was on the edge of her throne. A mountain nymph named Echo, 
renowned for her charm and chatter, was regaling her with a sensational story. But what Hera didn’t know 
was that Echo was merely distracting her while her husband, Zeus, was frolicking about 
with the other nymphs. Unfortunately for Echo, Zeus got sloppy,
and Hera realized what was going on. Enraged by Echo’s duplicity— and powerless to stop 
her husband’s adultery— Hera decided to silence
the nymph for good. From then on, Echo could no longer
enrapture listeners with her stories; she could only repeat the last words
another said. As her conversations became dull 
and her company undesirable, Echo grew dispirited. One day, while Echo was drifting
through the woods, she spotted a young man hunting deer. It was Narcissus, the stunningly beautiful
son of a river god and water nymph. After his birth, a seer had given 
his mother a cryptic prophecy: Narcissus would live a long life—
but only if he never really knew himself. No one was sure exactly 
what to make of this. And, in the meantime,
Narcissus grew into a proud youth. His good looks attracted many admirers. But he preferred to amble through life
on his own and left a trail of broken hearts 
in his wake. Seeing Narcissus there, 
Echo was filled with longing. Unable to initiate a conversation,
she walked after him. Soon, Narcissus heard a rustle, 
and called out, “Who goes there? Who are you?” Echo revealed herself,
but only repeated the word “you,” making her tone as endearing as possible
as she went to hold him. Agitated, Narcissus said, 
“Let me go, I can’t stay.” Echo could only counter 
with a plea for him to do so. Freeing himself from her embrace,
Narcissus snapped, “I’d rather die than have you love me!” To which Echo could only cry,
“Love me... love me.” Narcissus told Echo once more 
to leave him alone, then faded from her gaze. Echo wandered to a cave. And gradually, her heart grew heavy
and her body frail until all that was left of her 
was her voice, which the wind carried to vast,
empty places. Forever after, it could be heard 
reverberating through hollow caves and rebounding across lonely clearings. But this wasn’t even the first time
heartbreak over Narcissus had proven fatal. A young man named Ameinias had also been
cruelly rejected by Narcissus. Before his death, he prayed to Nemesis,
the goddess of revenge, that Narcissus would also one day
know the pain of love. She heard Ameinias’ pleas and, 
upon witnessing Echo’s fate, decided that it would be 
the final affront. It was time for retribution. So, Nemesis set Narcissus 
towards a clear, glassy pool. As he bent towards the water to drink, he caught sight
of a hauntingly beautiful young man. Never before had Narcissus 
seen himself with such clarity. He spent the day acquainting himself
with every glinting angle and glowing curl then passed the evening 
gazing at his reflection by moonlight and sleeping with his fingers
grazing the water. Days wore on, and Narcissus never parted
from his one true love. When he reached out, 
his double reached for him; and when he leaned in to bestow a kiss,
he also tilted his face. But when he tried to hold 
the bewitching figure, it disappeared. At last, Narcissus knew the agony
of unrequited love. Eating and drinking nothing, 
Narcissus too wasted away. His neck ached from bending over the lake,
and his legs became rooted to the grass. When the wood nymphs finally passed by, all that was left of him 
was a white and yellow flower bending towards its reflection. From then on, it was known as narcissus.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: While Zeus frolicked with other nymphs, Echo distracted Hera by:
Options: A. Doing dances, B. Playing tricks, C. Telling stories, D. Swimming
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the reason behind Hera's decision to silence Echo? Options: A. Echo's beauty, B. Echo's charm and chatter, C. Echo's duplicity in distracting Hera while Zeus was with other nymphs, D. Echo's rejection of Zeus' advances Correct Option: C
Question 2: What was the result of Echo's conversations after Hera's punishment? Options: A. They became more engaging and entertaining, B. They became dull and she could only repeat the last words another said, C. She became more confident in speaking, D. She lost her ability to speak altogether Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the prophecy given to Narcissus' mother by a seer? Options: A. Narcissus would live a long life and be loved by many, B. Narcissus would live a short life and die young, C. Narcissus would live a long life but only if he never really knew himself, D. Narcissus would be rejected by everyone he loved Correct Option: C
Question 4: What was the reason behind Narcissus' rejection of Echo's love? Options: A. He was already in love with someone else, B. He was afraid of commitment, C. He was disgusted by Echo's voice, D. He didn't want to be loved by anyone Correct Option: D
Question 5: What was the result of Narcissus' encounter with his reflection in the pool? Options: A. He became more confident in his appearance, B. He became obsessed with his reflection and couldn't leave it, C. He realized the pain of unrequited love, D. He was able to overcome his vanity Correct Option: C
Question 6: Who was the goddess of revenge that Ameinias prayed to before his death? Options: A. Hera, B. Nemesis, C. Echo, D. Narcissus Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the result of Narcissus' prolonged gaze at his reflection? Options: A. He became stronger and more confident, B. He became weaker and more frail, C. He was able to leave his reflection and move on, D. He was transformed into a flower Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was the name of the flower that grew from Narcissus' body? Options: A. Narcissus, B. Echo, C. Ameinias, D. Nemesis Correct Option: A
Question 9: What was the reason behind Nemesis' decision to punish Narcissus? Options: A. He had rejected too many people, B. He had been cruel to Echo, C. He had been unfaithful to Hera, D. He had not known the pain of love Correct Option: D
Question 10: What was the result of Nemesis' punishment of Narcissus? Options: A. He was transformed into a beautiful flower, B. He was turned into a statue, C. He was left with a withered body and a fading voice, D. He was able to move on and find love again Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

but only if he never really knew himself. No one was sure exactly

and his legs became rooted to the grass. When the wood nymphs finally passed by, all that was left of him 
was a white and yellow flower bending towards its reflection. From then on, it was known as narcissus.
